The all powerful Moses in a corner: How fitting an analogy to his creator Michelangelo. We know that Buonarroti spoke of Moses as his most significant creation. Since long ago, he has been moved to a more protected and contained, if you will thoroughly cornered, environment. We do this to protect him from a society no longer able to allow further intimacy with such an important work. Moses has his horns because a translation was made in error by a revered saint. The horns have wildly different symbolic nuances depending on one's point of departure.Eve is spoken of as if she came from the side of Adam because a translation chose "from the side of" rather than an equally valid and more threateningly enpowering option of "alongside". Symbolism is so important. Moses' chiseled face, some say, may reflect his creator's own frustration and anger with not being allowed to finish the whole tombstone memorial as projected. Who knows?What we do know is that another major leader from one society has been transformed to great heights once again, despite the ongoing unresolved tensions between the two. Moses as simultaneous great hero and outsider reflects Michelangelo in so many ways. Many revere the artist despite his personal values and choices, which in many ways might easily have condemned him save for his vast talents and utility.It's to everyone's credit that both Moses and his creator have found their way into our minds and hearts. Santa Maira Maggiore's a great basilica for yet another reason: its major role as a symbolic bastion for the disenfranchised or other we tend to ignore or overlook.

It's not that you can't see those parts without throwing some cash, you still can see them, but this didn't felt right to me. Anyway, you shouldn't miss this one!
Another must see!. Beautiful inside and out. Sometimes very crowded. Security has been stepped up but doesn't detract from what's here.
Holy Doors. it is outstandingly beautiful and extremely well kept..unimaginable the huge size of the basilica and the beauty of it

overwhelming. This church is one of the four archbasilica's in Rome, and is just awe-inspiring. We attended the 10:00 a.m. high mass in Latin, and although we understood little of the language, it was an experience we will always remember.
The nicest of the Basilica's. A stunning Basilica. There was a service taking place when we visited, nobody looked as though they were enjoying it much but it did have a very good turn out.

The biggest and oldest basilica dedicated to the worship of Saint Mary. I've been there on the day before Pope Fancis opened the Holy Door in December 2015. Usually at lunch time it is not crowded and I had the chance to walk around and be amazed at its quite discrete sumptuousness which I was not expecting. Like St. Peter's church, the more important they are, the more discrete in their richness they seem to be. It's a huge church which easily invites us to sit and think.
Lovely. The history of these attractions is fascinating but it all rolls into one in the end, write down where you go and something about it is my big tip because you will forget,lovely building

Best basilica in Rome. A beautiful basilica the resting place of bernini and a number of popes.the ceiling is a joy to behold and the artwork divine. It is far more peaceful than the Vatican and people treat it with far more reverence. Supposidly contains a piece of wood from the nativity crib

A lot of waiting, not too much substance. My family and I went to Sta. Maria Maggiore as part of our plan to visit all four papal basilicas. When we arrived, we decided to take the inexpensive tour. The few passé st of the basilica that we saw were interesting, particularly the mosaics on the old facade of the church, but what was available to see was limited. The limitation was exacerbated by the fact that the guides took Italian speakers and English speakers together as a single group, so when the guide was speaking in one language, people who spoke the other language were left to stand around, and it really was not possible to explore on your own. Finally, a word of warning: While on the portico to view the mosaics, don't touch the wire running along the edge of the facade. My teenage son learned the hard way that it is electrified.
Worth visiting . During the break had taken a short trip of this monument. A marvel of architecture and of religious importance. One should not miss while travel Rome.

Impressive both outside and in. This large church is easily visited if, as we did, one chooses to walk from the Colosseum to Piazza della Repubblica. Fair enough, it was not on our list of 'must do' things but we are glad that our route took us past it!
Beautiful 'church'. A beautiful church, a bit different than the other ones and therefore a nice to see in addition to others.

Beautiful church with an understated charm of its own. Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore,located near Rome Termini station is the largest church in Rome.The church is dedicated to the Virgin Mary.It is very beautiful inside and well worth a visit.There are beautiful mosaics on the floor and the architecture, while not as grand as the Vatican has an understated charm of its own.
A wonderful Basilica. I got the feeling in this place it had all you could want from a place of worship. It was a functioning hub, you could see how people doing what they do.

Well worth a visit.. We could see the basilica from our hotel room opposite and although it may not look very much from the outside, except when lit at night, it is spectacular inside. Despite being quite busy it did not seem crowded. The interior of the main basilica is very interesting and free, but it is worth paying a small charge to go to the loggia and view the mosaics as well as the helical staircase. Our guide was a very well informed and articulate young man who gave us a lot of information and answered questions well. Do go and experience this place.
Golden Experience. a wonderful religious experience. The art and historical significance is truly majestic. Allow time to listen to the recorded guide and immerse yourself in the Godly place.

Do not miss while in Rome!. Underrated, but it is one of the main papal basilicas in Rome. Thankfully, it was only a 5 min walk from my hotel and it is also extremely close to Termini station. If you are on the other side of Rome there is a taxi stand right on the side of the basilica. Absolutely beautiful mosaics, enormous, and rarely has any lines! The entire basilica is protected by fencing around so you cannot just use any entrance. Go to the Piazza di Santa Maria Maggiore (opposite of the Piazza on Via Cavour) and there you will find the security entrance. There are many, many churches in Rome but this is one of the most beautiful. Plenty of priests line the sides waiting to hear confessions and it will say on the door what languages they speak.

Don't be fooled by the slightly plain outside facade. Go inside.. One of the four major basilica's in Rome and absolutely gorgeous inside.We nearly didn't go, it looked almost plain ( in comparison with the other magnificent buildings in Roma) from the outside. But what a surprise when we got inside.It's free to visit and definitely worth going. It's beautiful. Every square inch inside is so nicely decorated.

Beautiful is a word too short to express this Basilica . A sense of peace and calm grasps you as you enter this holy place. The chapel on the left next to the main altar is very beautiful. Do not forget to take a look at the ceiling of this chapel. It's a marvel how these ceilings were painted. And don't forget to pickup a souvenir for your home!!
If you love labyrinths and early Christian churches.... What a wonderful edifice. The floor is covered with many labyrinths. Walk but one or two and find the meditative aspect.

Big and beautiful, but difficult to see some of the artwork. This is a very large building with many different areas to see. The floors were magnificent, but I was not able to appreciate the paintings on the ceilings and walls because they were poorly lit and too distant. Expect to wait on line to pass through security; we were there on a weekday in March and waiting about 10 minutes. The restrooms are outside the building, around the corner from the entrance; exit through the gift shop and follow the signs to the restrooms, which are down a flight of stairs.

Wonderful church. This is a big and wonderful church with so many details and nice paintings. It is close to the main train station and it is free of charge to visit it but you have to pass through a metal detector like at Vatican.It is a must see in Rome.

A gem. This basilica is a real gem. It is most beautiful inside and deserves to be on top ten places to visit. The ceiling is amazing and you can sit quietly and take it in in all its glory. Outside there is a square which is surrounded by some excellent restaurants and bars.
Near the train station. This church is a no miss, the atmosphere here is amazing, even when there are few sculptures in this place, you can easily know why Catholicism was so powerful on that time.

Unexpected beauty. We visited because we knew a priest serving here. There's a lovely story that the church was founded on the spot where snow fell in August at the command of the Virgin Mary. There are wonderful early mosaics round the walls, a silver reliquary holding fragments of the Manger of Jesus, beautiful marble floors and painted celiling. A wonderful place to spend quiet time. It is also one of the four major basilicas of Rome with a special door to go through to help you gain all the graces of the Jubilee Year of Mercy.
Nice but crowded. This basilica is another very impressive building of the so many in Rome. Since it is located rather central, it can get pretty crowded but is still absolutely worth the visist.

Beautiful. Less visited but extremely beautiful. We stayed across from this Basilica at the Mecente Hotel and enjoyed listening to the chimes throughout the day and into the evening. The lights at night were just beautiful.

Amazing. This Basilica was unbelievable.Huge! So much detail! It is free to walk in but you will pass through metal dectectors.Our hotel was minutes walk from here but I recommend a visit even if you have to travel

Nicest Italian church. We slept in the opposite B&B so we saw many times this beautifull church. We visited many others but it is the best. If you are in Rome you should go inside and I recommend you see it the night too because the illumination very nice.

Off the beaten path gem. Went for a walk and came upon this hidden gem of a basilica. No lines but what a treasure. Rivals the big name Basilicas. Beautiful ceilings and altar area. Has a great history with many relics. They hear confessions in both Italian and English. Worth the visit.
Ancient and interesting. This is a special basilica, built by layers commencing the first centuries up to the 17th century. The inside is huge and very rich
Amazing. This was beautiful did not know where to look first one of the first churches we visited and one of the most beautiful

Spectacular church. You don't have to go to St Peters to see an impressive basilica. This church has free entry and above all it is spectacular. Not just very imposing building it is crammed full of religious artworks and statues. We found this one of our best visits in Rome along with the Pantheon both are free entry.

One of many fantastic churches in Rome. We spent a week in rome and visited many churches. This is one that worth visiting. It is adorned with wonderful paintings and mosiacs. The Basilica has stood here approaching 1600 years and houses many treasures. The Basilica has a prominent place in the history of the Catholic Church This is one that should not be missed.
Beautiful Basilica. My fiancé and I visited the basilica on the first day we arrived in Rome. It was lovely and very peaceful, definitely worth seeing if in the area.

Looking across from the hotel. A beautiful building that encapsulates a time long ago. Entrance is relatively uncomplicated and easy access. However be prepared for the 'selfie sticks' pushed in your face.
So much splendour. With beautiful frescoes and gilt work this is quite a spectacular church and should not be missed. The queue moved quite quickly.

Beautiful. A very beautiful church definitely worth a visit. They told us that the paintings are better than in the Cistine chapel but as we never went I cannot comment but the paintings and history you feel as you walk around is incredible
excellent place to visit. our hotel was very close we went in side there is excellent paintings and carvings well worth the visit.

One of my favorites. grand. this is the first church i visited after i checked in from my hotel as his is about 20min walk away. I wasn't able to go inside though I just had my first selfie in Italy at this place.
missed seeing the inside: a huge church. We spotted it while checking our route to the Airport bus the following morning. What we saw was breath taking.

spiritual and unity. Go to Mass.every half hour

Wonderful church. One of the most important basilicas for a christian to visit in Rome. Very beautiful architecture and a peaceful place.

A quick stop on our pilgrimage of the 4 major Roman Catholic Basilicas. Santa Maria Maggiore was the second stop on our pilgrimage to the four major Catholic Basilicas of Rome. Like all of the major basilicas, armed guards were searching entrants. It only took a few minutes to get through the small security line. The exterior of Maggiore had a distinct clocktower, but was otherwise not extravagant. Dating back to the 5th century, the Maggiore is the largest church in Rome dedicated to the Virgin Mary. The mosaic paintings along the sides survive from the 5th century. Its 16th-century coffered ceiling is said to be gilded with gold initially brought by Christopher Columbus and presented by Ferdinand and Isabella to the Spanish pope.Below the High Altar is the Crypt of the Nativity, which includes a reliquary said to contain part of the Holy Crib carried to Rome by Christian refugees during the Muslim conquest of the Holy Land in the 7th century. Another attraction at Maggiore is the famous icon of the Virgin Mary known as Salus Populi Romani (Health of the Roman People), believed by some to have been painted by St. Luke the Evangelist, although most scholars date it to the 13th century. Bernini the sculptor is entombed at Maggiore.All of the churches in Rome are free to enter. Most include a tour guide listening station that for 2 euro will give 2 listeners 10-15 minutes of commentary including the history and significance of each church. I highly recommend these. Maggiore had a small gift shop, but it had noticeably less Mary-focused merchandise than the other major basilicas had of their respective apostles, which was disappointing.

The mosaics show a large influence of Byzantine art, and are very nice. The church also houses a chapel holding the tombs of 2 popes and the Bernini chapel. Both chapels cannot be entered, and are decorated in the barok style.

A venerable center of religion and art. S. Maria Maggiore was the first church dedicated to the Virgin Mary. It took 431 years for theologians to decide that she was both a virgin and the mother of Jesus/God, but once a council decided that this was so, it was possible for churches to be dedicated to her. This one has the general form of a Roman civic building (a basilica) with a higher central aisle (nave) and lower aisles, leaving room for windows in the upper part of the nave. A basilica often had identical columns leading to one or more semicircular end points of the nave. Churches usually had only one end point (the apse) so that people would focus on the altar that stands there. The evocation of imperial Rome was no accident, because the Roman Catholic Church gradually took over the administration of Rome as the senators moved out of town to their country estates while the administration of the city slowly disintegrated. (No surprise, since by then the capital of the Roman Empire had moved east to what's now Istanbul.) S. Maria Maggiore added to other early churches the sober, noble-looking forms of the Roman Empire and also added the earliest known imagery of the Virgin Mary's story, in permanent mosaic (small squares of colored stone and glass) over the arch leading to the apse. Then, along the walls above the columns, the sponsors commissioned scenes from the Bible, with some Old Testament scenes chosen to foretell episodes of the New Testament. Later, in the 12th century, other artists added images of the Virgin and Jesus enthroned in heaven (in the apse), and in the 16th century, side chapels were added for the burial of prominent churchmen and to provide additional spaces for worship. During much of the church's history, it became a place for burial of prominent people, primarily churchmen. One can see tombs of various dates in the middle ages and Renaissance and later periods. If you have binoculars or opera glasses, bring them along on your visit so as to have a better view of the mosaics, especially those on the arch and in the nave. They are not always easy to see, as the windows are fairly small and don't admit a great deal of light.

Holly Mary mother of God. It is the largest Catholic Marian church in Rome, Italy, from whence size it receives the appellation "major". The Basilica is located at 34 Piazza del Esquilino, some five blocks southwest of Stazione Termini.The Basilica is within Italian territory and not the territory of the Vatican City State.The original architecture of Santa Maria Maggiore was classical and traditionally Roman perhaps to convey the idea that Santa Maria Maggiore represented old imperial Rome as well as its Christian future.The interior of the Basilica contains precious mosaics such as the triumphal arch and a nave mosaic from the story of Moses.Under the high altar of the basilica is the Crypt of the Nativity or Bethlehem Crypt, with a crystal reliquary said to contain wood from the Holy Crib of the nativity of Jesus Christ.Here is the burial place of Saint Jerome, the 4th-century Doctor of the Church who translated the Bible into the Latin language.Just outside the Sistine Chapel is the tomb of Gianlorenzo Bernini and his family.

Majestic and beautiful. You will hear Roman people proudly boast this church as one of the most beautiful in Rome, the most beautiful as well as the oldest among the ones dedicated to Maria, the one with the most beautiful mosaics in Rome. All the above is to push you to visit this “papal” basilica, the one where apparently current pope Francis went first, just after his election, to pray.This monument is clearly a must. What impressed me more:- The two majestic chapels in the transetto, at the sides of the presbytery, especially the one named “Loggia del Sacramento”, located on your right looking at the altar. Just look at the extremely high, richly frescoed, bright and beautiful dome above the chapel.- The gilded paneled ceilings of the main nave, said to have been manufactured utilizing the first gold shipped from South America to Europe in XVI century, donated to the Pope by the Spanish royals.- The mosaics, obviously - There are three groups of mosaics: the ones in the vault of the apse, behind the altar, old and majestic, with clear byzantine influence, showing Maria’s Assumption to the heaven, sitting beside Christ – The ones in the walls along the main nave, smaller, located below the windows, not appreciable from a distance; some of them were destroyed by raising humidity in the walls of the church, and were replaced by frescoes – The ones in the “Loggia delle Benedizioni” (Blessings’ Loggia), above the main entrance, the only ones you can see close by; you will have access there with a guided tour (that I would definitely advise to join); interesting the difference between the mosaics at the upper level, in byzantine style depicting scenes from the Bible, and those in the level below, which already reflect the influence of Giotto, depicting scenes of everyday life.- The same guided tour to the Loggia delle Benedizioni will show you the helicoidal stairs which sparked the fame of Gian Lorenzo Bernini, the creator of the S. Peter Square world-famous colonnade, who is buried in this church. It seems that this is the first stairs built and functioning without central support.- In the museum below the church, don’t miss the beautiful marble statues of the first Nativity scene ever crafted, by Arnolfo di Cambio in XIII century (as the first Nativity ever was created by Saint Francis, live, a few decades earlier).

Behind a metal grill are the relics of the crib consisting of 5 pieces of the manger in which Christ was put at birth. I enjoyed the beauty and serenity of this Basilica so much that I went there twice.

A Religious, Artistic, and Cultural Treasure. The Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore is a religious, artistic, historical and cultural treasure. Just viewing the magnificent bell tower is stunning. The basilica is a kind of a living history of Europe from the 5th century to the eighteenth century.
A splendid Basilica Indeed!. Its an absolute must see and not to be missed. The old testament comes live. Its a marvel and treat to the eyes and mind. Do not miss.

Wow! Everywhere you looked, the Basilica shone!. Our tour guide pointed out the many beautiful Old Testament paintings that encircled the main part of the church and referred to it as the "First Bible" as the stories were told in paintings rather than in words. He then pointed out the gold-coffered ceilings and laughed as he told us that they were made of real gold brought back from the Americas because the Italian King and Queen had financed the trip! We were also taken in a room where there was a baptismal font and told that that was where Constantinople, the first Christian Roman Emperor had been baptized. That one had me scratching my head as I thought Constantinople had been pretty much on his death bed before becoming a Christian, even though his mother, now called St. Helen, was a strong believer and brought back many artifacts from the Holy Land.

Maggoire . Beautiful church that must be seen!! Plus it had the pieces of the original cradle of christ. Which is obviously very neat. Upset the archeological site is not free that would have been to cool to see.

Big church. Rating base on comparing different churches in area.. As with many places in Rome, the church is closed in the middle of the afternoon. So go in morning and after 3pm. Cool to see the purported nativity wood.

Basilica aglow in evening!. Last evening walk in Roma included stopping at this 4th century papal basilica. The stunning mosaics were shining thru the arches. This is one of 5 main basilicas in Rome and a very beautiful one it is.

Several must-sees in this Basilica. Beneath the main altar, remains of the Jesus Christ stable. The chapel on the left side of the main altar, wonderful decoration and ceiling paintings, not accessible during mass. Bernini's tomb, onthe right side of the main altar. Besides all these, the basilica is beautiful.
Beautiful. Amazed at the beauty of this Basilica! Walked to it from our Mosaics class and really enjoyed the art and mosaics here!

Magnificent church. Impressive by any stretch of the imagination. I imagine a lot of people stick to St Peter's, Vatican etc which may explain why this church was so empty. A little bit away from the main tourist areas, but it's still one of the four papal basilicas, beautiful inside and free with no queueing.
beautiful basilica. Beautiful old church. Beautiful art work. One of the 5 great churches to visit in Rome. A must on your Rome to see list.

Very beautiful. I couldn't find a surface they failed to decorate, and the whole place was very grand. Highlights for me were the silverware & kneeling statue in the area below the altar & the chapel to the right of the altar (as you're looking at it). Judging by the number of people in the pews with eyes closed it's also a good spot for a snooze. Cover legs & shoulders.

Beautifull authentic Roman column in the Basilica. It is a beautiful basilica. It is just too bad that so many churches were built with the stones and column froom the roman antiquity buildings. You can notice that the columns in the basilica are different because they come from various location. Overall it is a splendid church. One more big mausolea. It is very easy to see it when you walk around central Rome.

Get informed about guided tours in advance. THis is an amazing Cathedral. It is very old and one really needs a guide to be shown through all epochs, styles and stories that are depicted in the lavish interior. I am from an orthodox country and was amazed to see more Eastern motives, but again, the church dates back centuries before the Schism. There are guided tours which start at the museum. When you enter, turn right and go out to the crypt. There is the tourist info.

Beautiful, just beautiful!. The mosaics here are STUNNING! This combined with the picture behind the altar brought me to tears. Go in the morning when few people are here and make sure to wear pants or a long skirt. Make certain to go to the lower level to the tiny chapel. It is so peaceful and the sculpture of the praying pope is beautiful and heartwarming. Take time to pray and contemplate here. "Stuff" is going in this church though and one morning they barricaded the altar area and made everyone leave. No clue why. We came back another afernoon and there were no barricades and everything was open. The only thing I didn't like was that for the mosaics to be illuminated, you had to pay a euro and then the lights were only on for a couple of minutes. There is no way you could appreciate or see much in that amount of time. But it is stunning when the lights are on! TIP: they have clean bathrooms!
Beautiful architecture . Absolutely beautiful.The architecture of this place is beautiful and must be seen by anyone visiting rome and free to enter again which is always nice.

Nice side trip in Rome. Our hotel was a short walk to this basilica so we thought we'd take a look. And we were very glad we did. This is a beautiful church that captures the beauty and aesthetics of Rome.
Beautiful. Absolutely stunning,a must visit whilst in Rome.Everywhere you look there is another piece of history to admire and take in.Go early before it gets overcrowded.

don't judge a book by the cover. Did not expect much from this church, I was only walking past and thought Id stick my head in and have a look.I was blown away by the size of the place, its huge. there were some really interesting art work inside from famous artists.definitely have a look if you have spare time also the fountain outside is quite nice.
Amazing mosaics. This is a beautiful basilica with impressive mosaics. Make sure to spend a little extra time to take it all in.
A beautiful cathedral. It's very big and beautiful. It's well worth a visit. The artwork is stunning and church has a a wonderful history. One of the beautiful churches in Rome. It's a must see.
Beautiful and serene. Well worth a visit and perhaps stay for a mass. It is beautiful and so peaceful. The artwork is stunning and the church itself has a wonderful history.
Lovely. This is such a beautiful and important church. I could spend hours looking at everything and contemplating life's mysteries here. The piazza is filled with travelers from around the world.
Anazing Place. One of the beautiful churches in Rome. Must to see. You can plan some places in the center of Rome, they are close on to another.
Its closed. Wandered past this church on the way back to our hotel a couple of time and it was closed during the day on both occasions dont know if that is permanent of not

One of the most beautiful churches in Rome!. So thankful our food tour guide took us to Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore - such a breathtaking church. It sits in Monti, a very charming, safe, non-touristy Roman neighborhood. If you're visiting Rome and love churches, I recommend adding this one to your list.
Beautiful. This is one of the 4 Basilicas in the Rome area and although smaller than St. Peter's, it is beautiful in it's own right. Easily accessible from the hop on hop off busses.
What a surprise. I passed the back of this place everyday and never realised what it was until the last day of our vacation, we turned left instead of right, what an amazing site...

Stunning in all its power. This is just a beautiful building adorned with stunning artwork and statues. You can really feel the Power and the wealth of the Roman Catholic church. The queues are fairly lengthy but surprisingly swift to relinquish. I must have only waited for around 25 minutes before I was passing through the airport style security and was at liberty to wonder. Like anywhere in Rome and The Vatican the sights do exactly what it says on the tin - Simply, JUST DO IT!

Saw this at dusk. Maybe it was the time of day but we saw this just as the sun was setting. The church was pretty dark but because of that it felt very old and authentic. I would recommend going at this time of day to get the full affect. Great shopping and restaurants in this piazza!
Must see. Great Church, a must see durinh your Trip to Rom, well so are the 100 other small, big and huge churches..
Beautiful church. There are so many churches in Rome, this is one of the most beautiful ones in my opinion. Colourful paintings and excellent sculptures.

Although electric ... light a candle. We visited this wonderful church to light a candle for Grandma and we were amazed that the heat of the day and the noise were instantly left behind as we entered. The mosaics in the church were amazing and so was the roof.Compared to other places in Rome the church was not so filled with people … you could enjoy it.
A yawn when compared to others.... Big and boring... Check out Boromini's churches, or Quirnale, or the Bramante temple or St. Agnes. This one is nothing special in comparison.

Felt like a neighborhood church. One of the things I loved about my visit to Santa Maria Maggiore was that it felt like a church that real people used -- in fact, there was a baptism going on in a side chapel during my visit. It's lovely, not terribly crowded. Worth a visit -- even for those not religiously inclined (like myself).
Beautiful!. Our favorite of the 4 major basilicas. A little less traveled but well worth the visit. Be sure to stop in.
Comparison. Most impressive of the churches, rival the St Peters basilica at the Vatican, with the exception of the famous art works.

It's Closed. We are here in Rome for 7 days and have walked by the church 3 times only to find that it's closed. We were told this is a must see. Oh well. Have no idea when it's reopening. No signage or anything , just a huge fence around it.

Simply amazing one of the must sees in Roma. This Basilica was a highlight of our touring in Rome. The atmosphere, the mosaics the stained-glass windows, all exquisite. We enjoyed this Basilica tremendously. I would recommend everyone see this incredible site.

Stunning church. . This is a beautiful building with lots to see,opulent and artistic frescos on the ceilings and walls and lots of side chapels to look into.
The best thing about the visit was the fact that mass was being carried out in some of the chapels and the singing created a special atmosphere in the church.
One not to be missed.
Lovely church. Another lovely church. It did not rank highest on our list, but was a lovely tribute to Our Lady. Worth seeing.
Beautiful & solemn. Great mosaics. If you can get a private tour to see the balcony and private areas take advantage of it.
old fasion style. Tall long and lovely architecture style. All in gold and inside you will find stone from Jesus Christ stone where he was born. For somebody who believe it's amazing
Breathtaking Mosaics. This is a must see if doing the church route in Rome. Interesting history, very beautiful. Take your time and really look around, a guided tour well worth the expense.

Beautiful Basilica and well worth a visit.. Lovely basilica with a museum attached. The artwork in the basilica was an absolutely must see - not on par with the Vatican but still well worth seeing. Lovely afternoon spent walking round this lovely Italian church.

Lovely basilica in Rome. We visited this beautiful basilica on a rainy day.
They were hosting a very lovely intimate wedding. The priest spoke very kindly to the weds. It was inspiring and charming.
This is one of Rome's most stunning basilicas, featuring lovely, great marble statues.
Vatican Tour. Another of the Vatican Basilicas, another spectacular location. I'd recommend a guided tour, I went with Viator and they provided an air conditioned bus throughout the tour.

The greatest of the Roman churches. Whilst some churches can be over the top, to the extent of vulgarity in the case of St Peters, Santa Maria Maggiore is one of the most decorated and monumental of churches. It is the sheer space with its broad ceiling that first strikes. If you see no other church, then see this one.
Awe Inspriring. Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore is awe inspiring! It is soi easy for one to get lost in all it's beauty and rich history

Five days in Roma. We visited Santa Maria Maggiore once again.
I never tire of visiting this church. It is steeped in history and there is always something interesting to see that you did not notice previously.
I can recommend it.

Beautiful and peaceful. A truly wonderful basilica with wonderful statues and images. I hadn't planned to go but it was one of the best decisions I made. There is a really great sense of peace in there (and I'm not Christian). There are no charges and you are allowed to take photographs - which I recommend you do. Make a donation of EUR0.3 and you can light a candle too.

1 of many Basilicas in Rome.. There are many in Rome and each is different from the others. They all have their own history and their own beautiful. Take the time to visit and enjoy the art and the quiet time to reflect on the history and the beauty in front and all around as you stand there. Most do not allow pictures but some do. Ask or look for the signs. These are churchs as well as museums. .
St. Mary Major Basilica. Absolutely gorgeous Basilica with fantastic artwork, architecture and history. This is one of the top places to visit in Rome in my opinion.
Beautiful. A wonderful Basilica, well worth a visit. Stunning outside too. Only 10-15 minutes away from Termini station or a two minute walk from the city sightseeing bus tour bus stop.
Beautiful. Breath taking inside! You can walk here from the Spanish steps. It is also near many other sights that are interesting. Mass is said in Sunday's.
A chance visit.. An enormous Basilica with a beautiful painted ceiling, an amazing crypt with a large statue of a pope kneeling in prayer.
Amazing. Out of this world place! The sculptures, even the drains showing the passages below were beautiful! Amazing!

A must see when in Rome. We arrived in time for the tour of the Loggia. There were only eight of us on the tour which takes you into the Loggia which is part of the Vatican City. The Byzantine decorations are beautiful and you will see some very special artefacts.
Kneeling pope statue is amazing - must see!. Must see - especially the downstairs little section with the kneeling Pope statue - WOW. This place blew our minds - unbelieveable architecture.

amazing mosaics . the basilica is beautiful. We were taken and shown the totally amazing mosaics which aren't visible from inside the basilica. you have to climb a staircase to get to the top but once there its well worth the climb. The mosaics depict the story of a popes dream of snow falling in Rome and how the basilica came to be. There are also a spiral staircase that's carved into the wall and the four guardian angels in marbel and gold.The only negative of the tour was the fact that the guide spoke limited English so I think we missed some of her detailed descriptions. But that's typical English tourists expecting everyone to speak our language! The basilica itself is gorgeous inside. Typically Italian in design it is so ornate and the detailing on statues is just amazing.
Wonderful. We attend sunday mass and was amazingWe love the church Must visited wonderful Too many icons all over the church
Awesome!. Was probably the last church I saw in Italy and was still dumbfounded when I went in. Please don't miss this church. So close to Termani station. Put it on your list.

Stunning - finest Church I've visited in Rome. What I love about Rome is that you can visit any of the churches free and all of them are amazing in their own right. However this is by far one of the finest gorgeous and stunning churches I've had the pleasure of stepping inside. It's sumptuous, beautiful and so rich and vibrant. Was wonderful to behold, we lit candles for loved ones and I would reccommend anyone to visit if they get the oppurtunity.

Spectacular. My wife and I were in Rome to celebrate our 50th wedding anniversary. We visited Santa Maria Maggiore while on a driving tour of Rome. This is a beautiful example of churches built in the 5th Century.

Well lite!. Another church which more amazing architecture with very little line ups to get into the parish. Lots of art work and details of beauty. Worth the visit if you are in the area - but don't go out of your way to say I must see this church
My favorite spot. Way off the beaten path. Beautiful church with amazing hidden treasures. I love a church dedicated to Mary.. And it's free, unlike so many others.

PKovacich. This is a STUNNING church. We attended mass here before boarding the train to Florence(train station is a leisurely 5 min walk from the church). The church has amazing mosaics. It is well worth the trip and does not have the crowds like St. Peter's.

exquisite details. This was the first church we visited in Rome and it was beautiful! please go and visit and wonder at the talents that created the floors, walls, sculptures and ceiling of this church

A truly amazing building. This is well worth a visit, even in a city full of religious attractions. The scale of this church is quite amazing, and the artwork inside is breath-taking at times. It's also a nice escape from the bustle outside. Just sit in a spot for a while and take in the sights around you, then move up to another spot and do it again. Magic!

Beautiful. This church wasn't far from where we were staying and wanted to see this as it had such a good rating on here, I wasn't disappointed it is just beautiful, not busy at all and well worth making a trip here

another gem in the eternal city. As with almost every Basilica in Rome, stunning. We had not even had this one on our list, we just past it by luck, words don't do these places justice go see them for yourself.

Santa Maria Maggiore, you must go inside. We viewed this from the outside and had not idea of what awaited us inside. It is an incredible living church. We highly recommend a visit if in Rome, the architecture and history are truly remarkable along with the possible remains of the original manger. It looks so ordinary from the outside and is magnificent, spiritual when you enter.
2nd Best After Vatican City Church in World. Far better than expected, mindblowing, so much history carved on the walls , pillars and frescos in rome are awesome..

An unexpected surprise!. The basilica was down the street from our apartment. No waiting in line. Church is of course beautiful like all churches in Rome, but the surprise is outside the gift shop door to the museum. There are relics from the Apostles and Mary. Incredible!
Beautiful. A beautiful church. Also, very crowded. Nothing noteworthy to explore; I found other, less popular churches more of interest.
great church for whoever wants to pray. the church is on top of the pazza di spagna it is a very quite church big and peaceful and makes you want to stay there and pray.
Fabulous.. This was one of the best basillicas that we saw in rome, although there are so many there was no way we could get round them all.
Lovely. This basilicas is different from the ones i have seen so far, but it is quite lovely. So if you are close you should definitely see this.

Stunning!!. This was our favourite basilica in Rome. Visually stunning and very spiritual. A must see when in Rome. No queues and in our opinion more beautiful than st peter's basilica despite being on a far smaller scale.
Beautiful Basilica. One of the most beautiful basilicas in Rome. Art and atmosphere very serene. For those who chose to pray; they will have a very special connection with this place.

See a basilica from the time of Alexander the 6th. This is one of the most beautiful basilicas in Rome. Much of the gold decorating was done during the reign of Rodrigo Borgia, also known as Pope Alexander the 6th. It was absolutely amazing.
Breathtaking and humbling experience. Wonderful, breathtaking, humbling. Easy to skip this, but would recommend a visit. This really is a classic example of the diverse architecture free to visit.
Beautiful. Beautiful place to visit. Well maintained. Lots to see. Not to busy so you can easily stroll around without getting run over ! Take lots of pictures, it's a visit to remember.

A very beautiful Church, you really must see it. It is probably impossible to say which is the most beautiful church in Rome, but Santa Maria Maggiore must be up there with San Giovanni in Laterano. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful basilica, one of the oldest churches in central Rome. This Basilica is too good to miss because of the religious significance, the beauty of the architecture and decorations. It is one of the oldest churches in Rome having been built around 440 and is one of the best examples of an early Christian church in central Rome. The ceiling is said to be gilded from the first gold to have come the New World. In one of the side chapels is a painting of the Holy Mother and Child said to have been painted by St. Luke. Bernini is buried to the right of the alter; you can see his simple slab with his name.

Grand and Majestic. Step inside and see where your eyes will lead you. Details abound inside this beautiful church. Access to certain areas requires an access fee and can only be done at certain times. Plan accordingly.
Another beautiful church. We accidentally bumped into it while lost looking for our hotel it was a pleasant surprise couldn't get a decent outside photo but if you bump into it have a look
“Amazing place to visit in Rome”. A fantastic little gem, very close to the termini. Well worth a visit. You will need a scarf for your shoulders and longer shorts/pants for your legs.

Definately a place to visit. We visited this wonderful church and were amazed that the heat of the day and the noise were instantly left behind as we entered. It certainly added to the atmosphere. This church is very old, around 432 AD I think.and is the biggest church dedicated to St Mary , in Rome, hence the name Maggiore, or major.It was open and free to enter 7am to 7pm. Remember to be respectful and have knees and shoulders covered. They provide some cloth at the door but it is better to be dressed correctly. Entry was free but we didn't go further and pay for the. Museum. That was about €3. The mosaics in the church were amazing and so was the roof. It was nice to visit somewhere that was not so filled with people you couldn't enjoy it., like St Peters.
Small mass. We accidentally sat down as mass started at noon. Very beautiful and wasn't a full mass, so it was a nice addition to the day. Photos aren't allowed inside
One of the best basilicas . If you are in Rome then be sure not to miss this basilica. It is definitely one of the most beautiful. Its also an easy walk (10 mins) from the termini station.

Amazing place to visit in Rome. I was lucky visiting that awesome church, it was near my hotel and I was amazed with it's beauty, elegance, spiritual atmosphere, it gives a feeling that cannot be described. If you're in Rome, you should pay a visit to that Basilica
Stunning. A fantastic little gem, very close to the termini. Well worth a visit. Larger than life statue of the pop below the alter is amazing - the detail is simply stunning

is the wood from the Lords crib?. beautiful pictures, a larger than life kneeling statue of the Pope and separate underground chambers containing golden chalices's and wood reportedly from the crib of Jesus. all beautiful and with silk embroidered robes and paintings a plenty and wood reportadly from the crib of the Lord Jesus
Stunning. This is a beautiful Basilica! it really makes you feel so at peace. We did this with a group. You need a scarf for your shoulders and longer shorts/pants for your legs.

spectular. We stayed across the street at the Mecenate Palace with a gorgeous vie of the Basilica. This church is on the Pilgrim's Rome Tour featured in Rick Steve's Rome book. Interior is really spectacular with amazing mosaics and tombs of Sixtus V and Bernini.

Definitely worth a visit before you leave the Eternal City. If you have a few hours to spare before you catch a coach or train from the Termini please visit this beautiful Basilica.It is not on the scale of St Peters but impressive enough. The guards are quite strict on dress code so do make sure the lady has her shoulders covered and the gentlemen has shorts to the knees. There is packing fabric which you can borrow at the door but not very comfortable in warm weather. The church itself has an amazing ceiling and wonderful artwork. At the alter there is displayed the Manger which Christ was laid-how it came there I am not sure. This is a church not to be missed when visiting Rome.

Impressive. Impressive inside

Mosaics!. Peaceful place in the middle of busy street. Visited Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore suddenly when walking to hotel, tired of being shopping. Beautiful Basilica which hides total silence and peace in the middle of busy street.

Magnificence.. Words cannot describe the beauty of this magnificent Basilica to honour Mary, the Mother of Jesus. Be there. Speechless. There is no need to speak. Fantastic Basilica. Easy access from the Metro to this huge historical building. No charge to gain entry, well kept grounds and beautifully ornate Basilica. Well worth taking the time to visit!

Beautiful Basilicia. This a stunning Church which I stumbled upon. It has magnificent interior and well worth a visit. Less crowded than the Vatican and other Churches it is well worth the time to visit.
One place you must see. Really interesting and if you've got time take the archaeological tour that goes under the basilica and the museum, cost about 5 euros each extra and well worth it
check it out. basilica-style church renovated over the centuries. The marble and marquetry, elaborate coffered ceiling and statuary are all very impressive.
Wonderful. This is the most beautiful church I have ever seen. Well worth a visit. Easily accessible on the hop-on hop-off buses.

A Beautiful Church with beautiful paintings and ceilings.. It was a wonderful experience as from outside it just looks like another church, but the inside was more than breathtaking. The beautiful ceilings, artwork, Mosaic floors and architecture are amazing. Worth your time, beautiful. The churches in Rome are amazing and this is one of the finest. Was quieter than

Beautiful church. I always like to visit this beautiful church on top of a hill a bit away from the large crowds of tourists. The ceiling is amazing and you get this healthy, humble feeling when entering this church.

Gorgeous, simple gorgeous.... We visited this Basilica on our last morning in Rome since we were staying just down the street. From the outside, (particularly the back), it is relatively unassuming. The inside is totally different with breathtaking ceilings, artwork, floors and side-chapels to visit. This is one of 5 great ancient Basilicas of Rome with the original church site dating to the ~4th century AD and the current structure being renovated in the 18th century. We spent a week in Italy and toured a lot of churches - this would be in my top 3 or 4 and earns a "don't miss" recommendation (after St Peter's, and St Mark's in Venice).
Beautiful!. Beautiful and historic. Easy to access, centrally located. Quiet and not as crowded as other churches, so one can truly se its treasures. A must see
Gorgeous church. We loved this church. Beautiful paintings, architecture, ceilings are amazing. Very quiet and tranquil, a must see, just gorgeous.
Beautiful. This is another beautiful church/cathedral. There are so many churches in Rome, but this one is definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful mosaic. Beautiful building. It is well worth the tour to visit the mosaic at the front part of the building.
Beautiful church. I loved this church. We walked here from our hotel.They have a little gift shop on the side. Maury you items here. Much more reasonable than the Vatican area.

beautiful. when you are in Rome, it is one of the places you have to visit, it has a modest structure compared to other churches in Rome, but the inside is a must see.
Breathtaking. This is the most beautiful church. The paintings and the ceiling are incredible. Very quiet and tranquil.

Another must-see. Not far out of the way, but well worth seeing. Much history here. Art abounds. Surrounded by at least five other major must-see churches.
Fantastic. This cathedral was near our hotel, and when we arrive in rome this was attraction we visit, and what an amazing church to visit, is just beautiful, don't leave Rome whithout visiting it.

Breathtaking!. Wonderful! Came across this by chance as near our hotel. Really impressive, spoilt a bit by tour guides. Ladies with bare shoulders were asked to wear what looked like a piece of horticultural fleece! Ingenious use! Chains of St Peter (under canopy) were interesting!

Stunning cathedral. Please do visit this cathedral, even if you're not christian. It's really beautiful and was out of my plans, it was a grateful surprise. One of the most beautiful cathedral I've ever visited.
beautiful. This church is just beautiful! The details and the art is amazing. Knowing the age of some of these churches is awe inspiring!

amazing. this was just over the road from our hotel what an amazing beautiful monument well worth a visit i wore shorts as it was a very hot day they gave me a sheet of voile to wrap around my waist to allow me to enter this truely magnificent building

beautiful santa maria. the church is some how close to the train station, so kinda away from the other attractions which are located in the center it is absolutely beautiful , we went there on a sunday and we were lucky to witness their ceremony :)

Witnessed a wedding.. It was a sunday. Most churches were closed but this was open for a wedding. Tourists were flooding in but were told to stay clear of the central area for the wedding procession.
