No other church has the same effect, even St Peter's seems modest in comparison but with the added grandeur of course. Crowded at all times but you can lose yourself in the beauty.
Beautiful way to spend a few hours. The Basilica is far more impressive when you are in side. The artwork is just fantastic keep camera in hand there is so much to see. Far more than I ever expected
This is a church ; not an " attraction". A beautiful church. This is one of the churches in Rome large enough to be able to find somewhere quite and away from the hoards if tourists.

Worth seeing. This is just one of many beautiful churches. This one is dedicated to the Virgin Mary. The detail and statues and paintings are so beautiful. As in all churches in Roma make sure your shoulders and your legs to your knees are coverde

Worth a visit. SO close to the Terminus and well worth the short walk, a really beautiful and cool building which was most welcome in scorching weather, more serene than some of the other churches we visited
Beautiful. The Basilica is very beautiful. We stumbled upon it, and decided to go in since it was open. We enjoyed the visit very much.

Our tour guide and driver, Mauricio from Carratonitours.com took us here and explained the history and architectural details. Personally I would suggest going with our private tour as we had a wonderful time in Rome. This is one of many places worth going to, if you are interested in grand designs and unique artwork.

Beautiful, serene and worth a visit. This large Basilica is really beautiful and worth the visit. It is a further example of extraordinary works of art and carvings. The open plan confessionals in different languages was an interesting touch :)
Don't miss it. A lot quieter than St. Peter's and still just as important. We visited in the afternoon and it was very peaceful.

Great church. At the other end of the road from the church of St Giovanni in Laterano. Wonderful elaborate ceilings and rich marble throughout.

Stop in if you are in the area. This is not one of the few churches showing the most distinctive architecture or art, but it is nice, free, and for a small fee the guided tour provides an informative and enjoyable half hour of information along with access to areas not generally available to the public.

Stunning with ancient relics. This Basilica was stunning. The ceiling is made from the first gold shipped from the Americas. It also contains an ornate display containing fragments of the crib in which Christ was born. It contains lots of incredible small chapels, with the main alter dominating the floor area. Definitely a must see when in Rome.
Impressive from the outside, stunning inside. The interior is full of marble, columns, paintings, lots of side chapels all gloriously decorated and an impressive ceiling.
Disappointed. Much preferred St. Maria in Trastevere and Chiesa (Church) of St.Maria in Aracoeli in Piazza Venezia. Their interiors were much more attractive.
Great. Excellent place to visit in Rome. A great church and good to stay for a long time there. Be prepared to walk a distance from the train station.

Columbus Gold above your head!. An awesome and very living church that still breathes the power of Catholicism from every part of its Golden Coffer Ceiling. The gold is supposed to be the first gold brought by Columbus from the Americas
Amazing place. Stopped here by accident but what an amazing place. Its almost up there with St Peters Basillica. Lots of smaller churches inside and the sights are amazing

Beautiful Basilica. A very special Basilica with all the paintings, the domes, relics, What a wonderful magestic place!
One of the most beautiful churches I have visited
Oasis of Calm. Take 5 moins out of your busy trip to sit and refocus ion this wonderful, beautiful and tranquil master piece

A Graceful Church A Stones Throw From Termini. Staying in the Welcome Piram Hotel we were just around the corner from Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore. It certainly is one to stop and really take in. Not being hugely religious myself it was more for the architectural point of view and this church certainly does not disappoint.Would be a better visit for someone of the Christian faith but anyone can admire the beauty of the building itself.

Gorgeous church. This church, a prestigious papal Basilica, is quite special with fine painted ceilings, cuppola, domes and impressive statuary. A well-proportioned, elegant space inside and a handsome fountain outside. Its more modern circular stained glass window of the Virgin and child offers as arresting a focal point as any of the gilded monuments. A lovely spot to take a coffee break and watch the Roman drivers squeeze their way around the island on which the church stands.

The basement museum is a highlight. Santa Maria Maggiore is one of Rome's most important churches, and well worth seeing in itself. However, hidden underneath are the remains of a Roman house, and tours of the museum can be obtained. It only takes about half an hour, but the restoration that has been done is wonderful and really brings ancient Rome to life.

A must if you are Christian, but essential for its beauty. one of four major basilicas of Rome. many exceptionals mosaics of the basilica with those of the apse. the relics of the manger in Bethlehem.

If Carlsberg did churches..... The architecture was impressive and the frescoes awesome. It rates second only to St Peter's Bascillica in terms of clour and scale. Visitors to Rome really should visit this church even if you are not remotely religeous (I'm not)
beautiful basilica could compare to vatican. Never enough time to see all the beautiful art and sculptures. I suggest a little extra time for this gorgeous basilica.

Beautiful Church. A church worth a visit. Lots to see and absorb. The genius sculptor and architect, Gian Lorenzo Bernini is buried here. Other prominent Italians too. Recommended if you are in this locality of Rome.

Another great Basilica. This Basilica is well worth visiting, there is a series of fantastic mosaics up high around the Nave, very bright colours, depicting scenes from the Bible. Rich decorations throughout the whole church. Not as busy as many other churches in Rome, so much easier viewing.

Majestic & No Lines!. Amazing and beautiful Basilica. Everything has been said, believe it. And after you see it, buy the book in the gift shop. Excellent value @ €4.50, if you are interested in the history but on a budget and a tour is not on the cards. The fact that there was not a queue was a huge relief. The first church I visited in Rome and one of the best.

Simply Amazing. My husband and I love to visit churches when we travel in Europe. Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore did not disappoint. The architecture is stunning & the altar area is breath taking. The vastness of this basilica is overwhelming. It's wonderful to sit & soak up its beauty & grandeur.
Magnificent. Vast basilica well preserved.. Exquisite monument with beautiful mosaics.. Words cannot not describe sight..
one to visit. there is no dislike about this basilica.The work that went into building this basilica is acredit to who took the time and effort to build such an amazing church.

Worth a visit. We visited here on our first day in rome (myself, my partner, my 2 year old son and my 7 month old baby boy) it is absolutely stunning. Its definitely worth a visit it took us about half an hour in there. the statues in there are that fantastic that the face recognition on my phone picked them up. :)

Warning: Don't wear shorts.. I hadn't seen any information regarding a dress code for Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore, but there is apparently one. A selective one. Stunning church. Atmospheric church with great frescoes. Nowhere near as crowded as the more famous sites. Most hop-on hop-off buses stop right outside.

Definately a must see!. We visited this church as part of the Hop on Hop off tour but it was very surprisingly beautiful. It was not on my list, unfortunately, but I was really glad we visited it. spectacular. Even after several trips to Rome, neither of us had visited this magnificent Basilica, which was featured in art history classes. We are so glad we saw it! Not to be missed.

Astounding . Kinda stumbled over this place. Astounding, and you kinda need a minute or two to take it all in. We were lucky enough to hear a choir singing in the place, just a bunch of random people. Well worth looking out for.
Beautiful church and domes. This is a very large basilica that needs power washing on the exterior but the interior is fabulous. We highly recommend visiting it.

Must see. Visited as part of a hop on hop off tour - absolutely stunning, definately worth a visit! The surrounding area has good cafes and a little market, but I spend most of my time in the church admiring the beautiful marble, paintings and sculptures,

Wonderfull architecture and paintures. The second visit to this imressing basilica enabled us to be eshtonished once again : the paintures, the scultures and the hole interior is a beauty. In the night - the lights make the building and the tower look like a fairytale palace.

a magnificent ceiling and a beautiful baroque façade. A baroquissim façade, the highest campanile in Europe and one of the longest ceilings in a basilica, made of golden "boxes" supposedly from the first gold brought back from the "new world".

A beautiful church.. My cousin lives across the road from this church which I have visited many times. So I feel well qualified to comment. I think it is the second largest church in Rome and I never get tired of seeing it's beautiful interior.

Wonderful. The first church built to recognise Mary as the mother of Christ is worth visiting with a registered guide. The details and sheer volume of beauty and details inside is spellbinding and overwheming. We loved seeing it
Just blissed. I'm a Catholic - went to mass there on the Sunday and I cannot put it into words. It was very solemn.
Wow!. We stayed right next door so passed it several times. Finally decided to go in to fill a gap in the day and Wow - what a surprise. Amazing and a must see.

Ornate. This church was very ornate. There are plenty of crypts to see, and some of them are in the floor. It's worth a spin through for the history of it, but if you aren't Catholic, then there's not much else to it.

An unexpected gem.. We had passed this Basilica several times before finally deciding to look inside. We walked through the door and...WOW! It's huge and richly decorated. The only reason I haven't given it five stars is that we visited St Peters and The Vatican the day before and it can't quite match the scale and majesty of the former or the sheer glory of the latter.Santa Maria Maggiore offers glimpses of the greatest architecture and art without crowds, queues or admission charges. There is space and peace inside and the relative silence gives the place an air of holiness. Take time to sit for a while and absorb the amazing decoration.A real surprise - expectations exceeded. Basilica di Santa Maria Maggior. We fount this building very impressive all round, with a lot of history attached. This was rather spoiled by the state of the roads and the forecourt leading up to the Basilica
Interesting. Church was right across the street from our hotel. Had a fabulous clock on the floor that told the time with the sun coming in through the ceiling. Fabulous!

Impressive!. As we waited for the time to arrive for our dinner nearby, we sat on the steps in the Piazza di Santa Maria fountain and saw this beautiful Basilica in the corner, so I decided to go inside. It was somewhat early evening and we walked in on Good Friday Mass. I am so glad I did. This Basilica is so impressive and beautiful! Beautiful inside and out. A great and rich basilica that i didn't see in former visits to Rome, and it wasn't justified.The outer design is also very impressive, and ofcourse the inside is amazing.

A huge and interesting cathedral. Only a few minutes walk from the main rail station (Termini), a quiet sanctuary in the middle of a bustling city, a huge and very interesting church. Utterly beautiful. A gorgeous Byzantine church in a very chilled square - we saw a charming puppet show with a 'painter' puppet using real paint!Make sure you buy a short guided tour of the dazzling mosaics on the front of the church, really interesting and utterly beautiful.

Atmospheric Basilica with it's Holy ambience intact.. Santa Maria Maggiore is a beautiful church on the Esquiline hill. It's mosaics and multi surfaced marble interior are breathtaking, and with some further exterior mosaic work on the front face it is essential to visit. My favourite aspect of a visit (and I've been many times) is the ambient holy atmosphere. It exudes a warm welcome to all comers and you may be lucky enough to witness as we were, an informal choral rehearsal by a visiting choir group in one of the many side chapels of the Basilica. One of the many roads leading away from the Basilica, Via Panisperna, is a beautiful street which dips and rises twice as it takes you to the the back of Trajan's Market. I would recommend a walk along this street either to or from the Basilica.
BEAUTIFUL AND IMPRESSIVE. One of the most beautiful churches in Rome, in my opinion.There are tombs of many important Popes and Cardinals. Wonderful inside with beautiful mosaics.Don´t miss it!

A Basilica above the Rest. Appreciating this beautiful basilica, away from its religious association, is indeed easy. It is situated within the old section of Rome and dedicated to the mother of you know who. Unlike the other 3 Vatican churches, the Holy door is situated on the left, which is important to know, so that pilgrims end up touching the right door. Failing that, their wish will not come true. The interior is stunning as you would expect and a couple of former Popes are interned within. More of interest to me, is that Bernini, the great artist is also buried here, very near the altar. Ensure that you dress modestly and ignore the beggars that tend to congregate outside.The ambience of the basilica is very positive and this would be high on my list of places to visit.
All things bright and beautiful. The sheer beauty of this Basilica takes the breath away , a seat in solitude is essential to gather thoughts and view the wonders
One not to miss. Only really went here because we had time to spare but what a fantastic surprise. It is spectacular and could have spent so much more time here. Well worth a visit. Amazing ceiling.
Wonderful. I had the chance to listen mass and have the communion . Love it . Is a beautiful place, what a beautiful frescos, My husband is not catholic and love this church too.

Beautiful church. This was our favourite church in Rome. It is so beautiful, we lit candles for our parents who had passed away and gave a contribution for a mass for them. You can do this as envelopes are dotted around the church. Very moving experience, a must visit.

Majestic and serene. Although this is a place to see its also very much a working church. You will be inspired by the breathtaking beauty of this church will people sing hyms from several chapels conducting services.

Loved this basilica! Many things around it as well!. We stayed in a flat one block away from this basilica. It has been preserved nicely and sounds it bell at night. Our Beloved Santa Maria. 4 hours will not be enough to enjoy the entire place. This beautiful church is a must for anyone to spend time and learn of world class artifact!

Do not miss!!!!. This beautiful church (under statement) is a must see!!! We almost missed it, but managed to catch it the night before leaving Rome. It is spectacular!!! Really nice church. We stopped by while sightseeing in Rome, and did not regret it.

A must see stop in Rome. Just a short walk from the Termini rail station but well worth the time and effort. It is a beautiful Basilica and the artwork is amazing. Too Magnificent to Grasp. Located on the Piazza Santa Maria Maggiore, this is the only papal basilica in Rome to retain its original structure, and one of the earliest churches dedicated to the Virgin Mary. It is also one of only four major basilicas and is a church of legend; it is said to house pieces of wood brought to Rome from from the crib of Jesus' nativity. Over the years, many popes have made many modifications, of course--chapels, facades, the museum, and other tributes--but this is essentially the cathedral that has occupied the Esquiline hill since the middle of the sixth century. The scope of the frescoes and oils, the sculptures and mosaics, and the architecture (itself a sculpture) is impossible to describe. Perhaps, like all things of immeasurable beauty, that is as it should be. It is captured in a feeling. Do not exclude this from a list of places to visit while in Rome. Become a child and see it with your child's eyes and heart. NOTE: There is a fee for the museum, not for the basilica proper.

Ok for art but did not feel like a place of worship. I was disappointed by my visit today. I expected more from visiting a major church. The atmosphere of years of worship just was not there. I did not stay here anything like as long as the other basilicas in Rome. As much of the artistry is very similar you tend to look for something extra to stick in your mind.
Again an amazing basilica . I am repeating myself: this is a really beautiful church. Beautiful ceilings, floors, altarpiece, amazing. On Sunday there is also a small market behind the church.

Beautiful church. Beautiful church near termini station. Has a museum and guided tours available. Would love to see the petal ceremony in August. The square and area outside has lovely cafés and ice cream parlours.

Maria Maggiore. Amazing church. Went in not really knowing anything about it. The interior is stunning. It was right near our hotel so we popped in more than once.

Stunning. This Basilica was close to our hotel. It is absolutely beautiful and worth a visit. Very popular with tourists. Again the size is amazing. It is one of the four major papal basilicas in Rome

Beautiful inside out..... The first stop when you take Hop on Hop off… Its simply beautiful inside out and one of the five great ancient basilicas of Rome.Athenian marble columns supporting the nave are the oldest parts of the church, medieval bell tower which is the highest in Rome, the golden mosaics of the triumphal arch everything is admirable.

Superb basilica, in a more quiet part of Rome. Make sure to visit this great place, as it you will enjoy it much more. It sits in a piazza with much fewer tourists and vendors, so you will appreciate it more.

Simply beautiful. Well worth a visit as this place is simply beautiful. As you wander around take a look up to the ceiling, the detail and imagery is breath taking. Please don't do what some disrespectful visitors were doing and actually enter the service and take photos! There's a side chapel on the right hand side which has the most beautiful ceiling, the art is wonderful and just seems to lead you up to heaven - go and look up at it to see what I mean. Whether this is true or not I don't know but the atmosphere down there as well as the fact that you could be looking at the actual crib is pretty special. A beautiful place which even our 11 year old daughter could appreciate.

Beautiful!!. The ceiling of the church is breathtaking. Its one of the ch8urches directly under vatican. So, if you use the Roma Christina tour, it includes a audio guide for this place and gives you an entry to the crypt as well.

beautiful. art is amazing after all these years still looks great, ceiling is unbelievable what a nice piece of work worth a visit

What a church!. As the only Roman Catholic church dedicated to the Virgin Mary in the entire world that was directed by Mary herself to be built (though a vision to Pope Liberius in the 4th century), this church holds a very special place in Roman Catholicism. It is due to this and not its size that it gets the title of maggiore (major). It is the center of the Marianist Society and holds what is thought to be the oldest marianist symbol in the world, a 12th century mosaic of the madonna and child. It is also a Papal Bascilica and therefore holds the remains of many popes as well as St. Jerome. The left transept is particularly beautiful with its many different colors of marble and its sculptures and paintings. Well worth the visit and only a few blocks from the B line Metro station of Victor Emmanuel.

Beautifully. This is one of the first Christian churches in Rome. He was already 1600 years. Very beautiful mosaics on the walls and sculptures. Rightfully one of the most beautiful buildings in Rome.

Amazing church. We visited as part of our hop on hop off bus tour. This Basilica was truly breathtaking and well worth a visit. The ceiling is amazing. The service that was taking place was beautiful, it gave me a sense of peace and tranquility. I would definitely go back again.

Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore. Outstanding , increible, you better take a guid tour to understand many important things you will see, to understand the loggia delle bendizioni and all the other rooms, ...you will love it

Nothing new about this sight? Well, perhaps too! For serious art-lovers..... --and anybody with patient good will can become a serious art-lover: so plan a little extra-time for your visit of this outstanding sight (don't have to enlarge on its tremendous riches) and take a guided tour of the loggia delle benedizioni and adjacent rooms, most importantly Bernini's winding stair--and of the excavations underneath the present church. The late 13th c. mosaics in the loggia, although heavily restored, in instructive and entertaining fashion supplement your knowledge of Roman painting (and musivic art) of the period. Then there are a few sumptious vestments in the sacristy, but above all, Bernini's engineering feat of a winding stair without central support! It is impressive in its plain, but outstanding craftsmanship. The excavations offer a glimpse into the Roman period 'pre-history' of the present, 5th c. building, including rich marble panelling, fresco paintings, and a fascinating collection of Roman roof tiles with imperial monopoly stamps right down to and including Theodoric! Not to forget: our guides were great, both knowledgeable and gracious (it might help you to have a smattering of Italian...).

Top Esquiline hill attraction. Note none of this costs you anything.We are not religious, but I should think anyone can appreciate the architecture of these churches and arch. Whether you should go out of your way to go and visit them is another thing.

Imponent and fierce!. Again, forget about the popularity of St Peter's Church and pay attention (or at least try to do so) to the details and richness of this church...it's unique, stunning, true beauty!

A Basilica not to miss....... Close to Piazza della Repubblica is the basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore and a stop you should add to your visit.The Basilica is on the Esquiline Hill. It has the relic of the Holy Crib, shards from the Holy Manger, a piece of the True Cross, and the tombs of St. Matthew, St. Jerome, and Pope Pius VThere is as part of the church a Romanesque bell tower which rises 75 meters high and is the tallest in RomeThe church is a stop too often missed by visitors to Rome. Don't miss one of the largest churches built for the Virgin Mary.It is worth a visit.

the largest Catholic Marian church in Rome. The Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore, is the largest Catholic Marian church in Rome, Italy. According to the 1929 Lateran Treaty, the basilica located in Italian territory is owned by the Holy See and enjoys extraterritorial status similar to that of foreign embassies. Fantastic Architecture. I love historical places, the story behind them and the architecture as well as out of this world. Photos don't even get close to demonstrating the true beauty observed b y visiting.

A Basilica not to miss.. There are quite a few in Rome but this is one of the best. There is a lot to see and it left me in awe. Be prepared for another stiff neck as you spend a lot of time looking up.

One of the most incredible cathedral's on earth!!. The Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore is the cathedral dedicated to the Virgin Mary (Santa Maria Maggiore = St. Mary the Major, the Holy Mother) It is one of the oldest churches in all of Christendom. It is one of 4 Papal Basilicas, i.e. the Pope is the Rector (notice the Papal Throne on the high altar?) the burial place of Bernini, the burial place of 2 popes and the family church, and crypt, of the Borghese's. The ceiling is covered in gold brought by Christopher Columbus from the New World back to Spain, then donated by Queen Isabella to the church. To this day architectural students travel from around the world to study Michelangelo's chapel and Bernini's spiral staircase. Perhaps it's most important relic, located in the attached museum, is the actual manger of Jesus Christ. This Cathedral was the first place Pope John Paul II, Pope Benedict and Pope Francis visited upon becoming Pope. This is one of the most amazing Cathedral's on the planet and equal in importance to St Peter's.

Papal Basilica found by accident!!!. The second church that my wife and I found by accident (the first being Sant Andrea della Valle), the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore is absolutely beautiful. Since we had saved a little time on our itinerary at one of our previous destinations, we decided to take a peek inside Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore. Once inside, we were met with an enormous church with a long nave culminating with a large triumphal arch. Inside the church, there are many extremely important artworks as well as the burial places of Gian Lorenzo Bernini, numerous Popes, and Saint Jerome, who was responsible for the 4th Century translation of the Bible into Latin. All in all, the Papal Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore is filled with history and, at worst, worth a short visit when in Rome.

This is one of those things you can't miss visiting in Rome. I've been to Rome numerous times, and EVERYTIME I make it a special point to visit this basilica. Beautiful church with stunning mosaics!. This is one of four major basilicas in Rome that no one should miss. In 16th century the "Sistine Chapel" was build by Domenico Fontana and later F. Ponzo designed the Pauline Borghese Chapel in the beautiful baroque style. The church is the place of the tomb of Bernini, Italy's most important baroque sculptor and architect. Many visitors find this basilica more beautiful than St. Peter's in Vatican. Come and judge for yourself! Highly recommended!

Holy Saint Mary Church - Must Visit !. Holy Saint Mary Church - Must Visit !Basilica of Santa Maria MaggioreSanta Maria Maggiore is one of the four Patriarchal Basilicas of Rome. Its construction was ordered by Pope Liberio who – they say – on August 5th 356 saw the Virgin Mary in his dreams. She indicated him where to construct the church through a snow fall that happened on the Esquilino Hill (this is the reason why the church is also called by the second name of Saint Mary “ad Nives”, of the Snows). It seems, however, that the actual Santa Maria Maggiore Basilica was built under Sisto III who erected it and dedicated it to Mary’s motherhood, just after the Council of Efeso in 431. One needs to notice that since the times of the late empire the Esquilino Hill had hosted a small temple dedicated to Giunone Luncina protectors of births, to whom matronal feasts were dedicated. Internally, in spite of the various interventions, the church has maintained the 3 aisles of the V century, separated by 40 monolithic marble and granite columns. In 1288 Niccolo IV ordered the construction of the transept. Alessandro VI (1254-1261) decided the building of the central aisle’s ceiling, for which – according to what the tradition says - materials arrived directly from the New World because of the Spanish origins of the Pope.The bell tower with its pyramid-shaped point dates 1300, and with its 75 metres it’s the tallest in Rome. In 1500 the side chapels were added.

Amazing Mosaics in Roman basilica. The main attraction of this ancient church (built by pope Sixtus III in the first part of the 5th century) is the are the splendid mosaics in the nave of the church, depicting scenes from the Old Testament. Unfortunately, the small panels are high up and details are hard to make out if you don't bring along binoculars. The 13th century mosaics of the apse (modeled after 5th century originals) executed by Jacopo Torriti) however, are easily viewed and present a stunning and moving image of "The Crowning of the Virgin." The church is very close to Termini station and is a gem.

Overwhelming Experience. This was the first of the 22 churches I visited on my recent week-long Rome trip. It was one of the best introductions to the city and its resplendent style of church that I could have imagined. It is opulent, as so many Roman churches are. It is large and imposing, as so many Roman churches are. It oozes history, as so many Roman churches do. It drips art, as so many Roman churches do. But, you have them all together here in one of the four key basilicas in the city. The facade stands proud beyond its large piazza, whilst sporting the highest campanile in the city; the coffered nave ceiling is encrusted with the first gold back from the Americas; the apse mosaics sparkle still despite their age, inserted only around 100 years after Constantine allowed Christianity headroom in the Empire; while it also boasts its very own and colourful Sistine Chapel. The paintings high up above the nave arcades are quite hard to see - unless you go on the tour of the loggia (nominal charge) where not only can you peer through at them from the roof, but you get to see the magnificent C13 mosaics above the portico as well as other parts of the basilica not usually seen. Add it to your list. See the exterior by night too - breathtaking.

The Basilica is strong and impressive. Once inside you need to prepare yourself for a massive explosion of Catholic showmanship! The ceiling is covered in the first gold brought from the New World, there are mosaics that are mind-blowing and sculptures that stop you in your step. The whole place is a celebration of religious devotion, prosperity and art. The history of this place is staggering and not to be missed.

Hidden Treasure- Why is this not on the "Must See" List?. My family stayed at a little hotel about 1 mile from the Central Train Station in Rome for a week. Since it appears that all churches in Rome have outdoor water fountains, we decided to see if this nondescript church we'd passed so many times had one to.We were shocked to see armed carbineri in front of the church. What could they possibly be guarding? We found the expected water fountain, and decided that we needed to go inside. Again, more armed carbineri greeted us when we entered.Wow! When Columbus made his most successful voyage to the Carribbean, he brought back a huge quantity of gold. Much of it was used to decorate the inside of the basilica. I stood for several minutes in awe just looking at hundreds, perhaps thousands, and beautiful paintings and tile work created over a 500 year period. A security guard named Luigi saw me, heard me speaking American English to my wife, and asked if I would like to tour. Of course, we accepted. For the next hour, we went through sections of the basilica that I do not believe are usually seen by the public, but Luigi assured us that we were not violating any restrictions.I would suggest adding this basilica to your itinerary in Rome. It certainly does not have the same panache or fame as other landmarks, but it is worth the trouble. I would go online and read a brief history of the church and its artwork, so you will not be as overwhelmed as I was when I first entered the building.

Walking on the lazy lanes of Rome, we got side tracked almost as if by purpose and through maze of seedy lanes reached the awe inspiring sight of Santa Maria De Maggiore. Santa Maria Maggiore is one of the four Patriarchal Basilicas of Rome.It is said that the construction was ordered by Pope Liberio who on August 5th 356 saw the Virgin Mary in his dreams. The intricate and grand interior retains its original 5th-century structure, despite the basilica having been much altered over the centuries. The nave floor is a fine example of 12th-century Cosmati paving. Ferdinand Fuga's 1741 facade is baroque, as is much of the sumptuous interior. The ceiling by Sangallo is gilded and said to be the first gold bought from the new world, given by Ferdinand and Isabella of Spain. The basilica has one of the most beautiful 5th-century mosaics in the triumphal arch and nave, depicting Old Testament scenes. The altar itself is a porphyry sarcophagus, which is said to contain the relics of St Matthew and other martyrs. A plaque to the right of the altar marks the spot where Gian Lorenzo Bernini and his father Pietro are buried. Steps lead down to the confessio (a crypt in which relics are placed), where a statue of Pope Pius IX kneels before a reliquary containing a fragment of Jesus' manger.The sumptuously decorated Cappella Sistina, last on the right, was built by Domenico Fontana in the 16th century and contains the tombs of Popes Sixtus V and Pius V.This is one place where religion and art come together into a holy union whereby one is transfixed by the sheer grandeur of the art and its opulence, wealth, and ability to mesmerise the audience in to a spiritual stupor. One needs a lot of time to explore this basilica in its entirely, and most of all to absorb the beauty of it all. This was one of our best finds in Rome.

The Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore is the number three church in Catholicism behind Archbasilica San Giovanni de Laterano and St. Peter's Basilica in that order. Although the Pope takes up residence in the Vatican City, his official seat is San Giovanni de Laterano.Santa Maria de Maggiore is a beautiful church that crowns the Plaza de Santa Maria in Rome. Catholic churches, like any place of worship, should be toured with quiet reverence because the faithful worship and pray there. There are many beautiful side chapels lining the sides of the Basilica and it houses a treasure trove of artwork by the great Renaissance artists.It is a "don't miss" attraction for any lover of the arts. Magnificent mosaics. Absolutely beautiful basilica, with magnificent mosaics and those mesmerizing Cosmati floors (it pays to both look up and look down in Rome!) We were there (again) today with Context Rome for a terrific walking tour focusing on medieval mosaics, which included worthwhile visits to two nearby churches, Santa Pudenziana and Santa Prassede. The apse mosaics here, as well as those on the preceding arches (which are very detailed), are breathtaking. On the apse, Christ and the Virgin are enthroned, surrounded by colorful winged angels, with a complex curving vine growing around them. Definitely a "must see" when in Rome, and a place that you really need to see multiple times to fully appreciate. And, I always love the story about how the basilica came to be, with a miraculous snowfall in August, 352 C.E.

Absolutely beautiful and a great basilica for mass if you are staying in the Quirinal area. My mother and I came here three times during our one week stay in Rome. The first time was on the day we arrived because it was about a 10 minute walk away from our hotel, Hotel Aberdeen, and also because it was my mother's favorite place to sit around when she stayed in a refugee camp in Rome 30 years ago. Unfortunately the famous stairs at the back of the basilica are now closed off (probably because so many bums kept sleeping on it), but the inside is more fun anyway! The other two visits were for mass.They perform smaller masses in the Borghese Chapel in the afternoon and mornings (up until 9 or 10 o'clock, then they have masses in the nave). For the smaller masses, the nuns do most of the singing (they sound like angels) and all of the other fellow church goers participate in the mass; as for the larger masses, the clergy members do all of the singing in Latin (very haunting!) and a bishop takes care of all the speaking parts.We went to the mass for Assumption Day, and there were flowers everywhere along the altar; it was very beautiful!The 13th century mosaics on the apse and the Triumphal Arch are absolutely gorgeous and very well preserved.Underneath the high altar is a very famous reliquary called the "crypt of the nativity," and it is said to contain wood from the crib of Jesus Christ. Regardless of whether or not you believe that is really true, the reliquary is beautiful, and the area underneath the altar is also where St. Jerome is buried.Also, if you walk around to the right of the high altar, on the floor near the raised platform you will see an engraved stone memorializing the tomb of Gianlorenzo Bernini; never would have thought he would be buried here!There is a quaint little gift shop and bathrooms on the right side of the basilica, as well as an underground museum founded by Pope John Paul II in 2001. You have to buy tickets to get into the museum, but they are not expensive and it is worth it because it is kept very cold and contains Roman artifacts that were discovered beneath the basilica in the 18th century in addition to many lovely altar pieces, paintings, and other religious items from the 16th to 19th centuries.This was my favorite basilica in all of Rome; I highly recommend visiting.

After much research I tentatively zeroed in on Santa Maggiore, mainly for it being high on the beauty quotient since it wasn't a religious visit.And i'm so glad we did. The church is breathtaking. A large main Hall with stately columns, marble inlay flooring,an arched and painted ceiling and a handsome altar. But its the side rooms that are truly fabulous. The paintings on the ceilings in these are gorgeous and framed with golden moldings. So if like us you are going to visit one church while in Rome- the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore is a worthwhile and memorable choice.

A wonderful basilica, filled with art treasures. The Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore is one of the most beautiful churches in Rome. I have visited it several times and each time it seems fresh and new. I love to sit, at first and just look around me. Even the floor is beautiful. Most people never look at the floor. Then there is the ceiling, with its lovely golden roses, made from the first gold from South America to reach Spain. The Emperor made a gift of this gold to the Spanish Pope, Roderigo Borgia. The central rose (not gold) is decorated with his coat of arms. There are many side chapels decorated with gorgeous works of art, which also adorn the body of the church . Last time I visited, May 2014, a society wedding was taking place in one of the side chapels. It was great to watch the splendidly dressed guests and the bridal party arrive.

Historic and impressive. This was the first church dedicated to the Virgin Mary in about 440 CE. (It took that long for church leaders to decide that yes, she was really the virgin mother of Christ.) It has the form of a Roman basilica (civic building) with a nave separated by columns from the side aisles, because dignity and authority under divine protection were associated with this architectural form in ancient times. It has been imitated many times since, albeit usually in smaller size. There are mosaics of the 5th century along the nave walls and on the arch framing the apse. Those in the nave show Old Testament subjects that Christians related to aspects of their newish religion. Later mosaics decorate the apse itself. Around 1600 two chapels were added near the apse end, containing lavish sculptures and altarpieces and other artworks. The one problem here is that the mosaics are hard to see because the nave windows are small and do not admit much light. If you look in any survey book in art history, you will see at least one of the mosaics illustrated.
Stunning Medieval Church. The sheer size and opulence of the church is staggering and a must see for any visit to Rome. This is the first church to be dedicated to the Virgin Mary

Stunning. It took us a while to find the entrance but once inside it was stunning. There was a mass on, which added to the atmosphere. Beautiful. It takes your breath away. There is so much to take in. We went into the little museum after our visit. A lovely place to visit.

Look big and decrepit outside. It's free and amazing inside, I mean seriously beautiful. I wandered for an hour looking at the overall splendour and the detail. It's on the hopon hopoff bus route the stop before the rail station. While I'm at it it recommend the yellow buses for the hoho route. Thinks it Christiana bus company or something like that, less crowded.

A hidden gem. The rear of this building faces via Cavour which is a busy street and this is deceiving as the entrance is off the Piazza on the other side and once inside be prepared to take many pictures as this is a stunning building

One of Romes greatest Basilicas. The church dates from the 5th Century,and is richly decorated with the most splendid Byzantine mosaics.The Basilica dominates the city of Rome,and has done for nearly sixteen centuries.The church also contains the rather plain tomb of Bernini,one of the greatest artists and sculpters of Rome.

Magnificent, except in Rome. By Rome's standard, it is a moderately ornate cathedral, with many very beautiful and attractive features. If it had been in any other city, it would have been one of the highlights of my visit. But now, two weeks on and after visiting many of the city's churches over a number of years, I can think of nothing outstanding about it, other than its size and its superb setting. Perhaps I need to go when it is quiet or to attend a service, but on my mid day visit, I was disappointed at the absence of the peace that is Rome's churches and of the absence of significant distinguishing characteristics.Rome has so many glorious places of worship, from the majesty of St. Peter's to the beautiful simplicity and serenity of San Giorgio in Velabro, that I cannot say that I would choose to visit or worship in Santa Maria Maggiore. Rome has so many that have more to attract me.

Awesome!. Have been to Rome several times, first time I had enough time to just wander around and found myself in front of this basilica. What a moving and beautiful place, could have spent hours just wandering around. Make a point to visit next time you are in Rome.

So many churches, so little time....include this on your list for the mosaics. You can spend a month in Rome just visiting the cathedrals and churches and at some stage get burn-out. So, before that happens, make sure you visit the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore.One the most ancient of Rome's Basilicas and the interior decor is magnificent. There are also some of the best mosaics in Rome on display here. the apse mosaic by Iacopo Torriti (1295) and the triumphal arch with a 5th century mosaic are also very special as is the alter canopy by Ferdinando Fuga.

A Beautiful church with a festival on the fifth of August!. We went on August the fifth at 9pm and there was a small festival celebrating the snowfall that fell in August to indicate the spot where they should build the church. The festival is called "Festa della Madonna della Neve" celebrated each year on August the fifth with a religious ceremony and artificial snowfall with white rose petals falling on the crowd. It was a beautiful event and the church is just magnificant.
Beautiful. My husband and I stumbled upon this church by accident as we were walking through avenues of shops. It is such a beautiful place with intricate marble, statues and paintingthroughout.

Oh holy god.. i'm an atheist, i don't shout about it, Going to the Vatican was not too high on my to do list while in rome.I like getting up early in the mornings on holidays and slipping out to see the real city while others sleep.this time the good wife woke and wanted to go with me, so 8am off we went for a walk, seen this big building, had to know what it was, some place.If you have the opportunity go and see it, go up to the main pulpit, you can go down below the alter and at the back there is a picture in the distance, very erie, it's some place.

Stunning and beautiful church. This is a stunning church near to Termini station in Rome. The exterior looks impressive, but the inside is astonishing in the beauty of its decoration, including the ceiling which supposedly is covered with the first gold Columbus brought back from the New World!We were lucky to be present earlier in the week for the ceremony held outside the church on the 5th August, celebrating the legend of snow falling on the hill and leading to the church being built. Worth seeing for the artificial snow fall!
impressive. Very beautiful and for 12 euros good value for money to see the museum, crypt and basilica. Reached it from the hop on hop off bus which was really good.
Absolutely Beautiful. I love this church, it is my favourite in Rome, the paintings and monuments in the cathederal are stunning, I will certainly be back on my next visit to Rome.

Inspirational !. A beautiful basilica not far from our hotel. Not as crowded !along it a !ore serene experience. I happened to visit as the cardinal celebrated mass. If you ever encounter such a situation, I highly recommend taking a deep breath, discard your tourist cap, and soak up the experience. It is truly a soul calming experience. You will exit the basilica rejuvenated.

Magnificent. A magnificent church that can only be found in Italy. This 5th century church is one of the oldest and most beautiful in all of Italy. A free attraction that is easy to get to and easy to see.

roma ... It was really nice, jou should just be aware of what are you wearing..we went in summer time,july,and we werent covered...so ee had to buy scarfs, just make sure your legs and shoulders are covered. Great experience.

What a spectacle!. The cathedrals were breathtaking. Needs days to fully appreciate the magnitude and depth of the architecture and design of the building. It's like paying homage to something greater than life.

WOW!. This beautiful basilica is dedicated to the Virgin Mary. It is absolutely stunning inside. There is a main church, with smaller chapels in it. Mass was going on in some of the smaller chapels. There are old time free standing confessionals and priests ready to hear confession. There is an area where a piece of the manger is on display. Many visitors (myself included) commented that the area where the manger is on display felt very sacred. Below the church, there are guided tour (for a small fee) that show a house that the church was built on top of. It is very interesting, and we all enjoyed seeing what remained of this Roman home. If you are wearing shorter shorts/skirt and have bare arms, the guards will provide a free paper shawl to wrap on shoulders or waist. This was one of my favorites places in Italy. There is no charge for admission and photography was permitted even though the signs posted said it wasn't.
Wonderful back story. This church is magnificent and the largest in the world dedicated to Mary. She came to a priest in a dream and a miracle followed and the church was built. It's a great story...

Stunning!. This Basilica looks nothing from the outside but step inside and words are not enough to describe what you see. This was the first Balisilica we saw and were left speechless, in total awe of the ornate decoration, marble and statues.
Definitely worth a visit but take care with the beggars who are outside.

Definitely worth a visit. Beautiful architecture, peaceful, amazing artwork, phenomenal, some lovely cafés and restaurants nearby, close to termini.
A memorable visit

Attend Sunday mass. Like many churches in Rome this is a highly decorative with beautiful artworks and ornate smaller chapels. If you attend Sunday Mass you will be alongside local Italian families dressed up for church. Don't forget dress modestly and cover you shoulders.
Simplistically perfect!. A beautiful Basilica with some interesting pieces. Very close to the station and another lovely fountain!
worth a look. Superb but doesn't quite match the Vatican or St John Lateran. Any other city in the world and it would be out on its own

Worth the visit. The is a large impressive church, with a museum that is also worth a visit.
The art on display is excellent and it is worth the visit for this alone. The museum includes a large collection from the Vatican.

Fantastic place.. This was fantastic. The artwork was unbelievable. Ladies can't have bare shoulders or thighs so make sure you're covered up. I could have taken hundreds of pictures in here as it's so beautiful.
Secrets inside!. Whatever you do, take the guided tour! Bernini and borghese await behind hidden doors! An absolute must with a lovely tour guide!

Beautiful!. Feeling..........the Art Work (why pay to go to MUESUMS) ! Be FORE WARNED.......... Gypsies do hang out or inside of doorways of all the Churches ........its confusing they almost act like there is a fee of entrance. Its a caught off moment...keep this in mind. Largest Church in Rome. Very good historical church in the city. Services are available to all for confession, mass or prayers.
Awesome. Breathtaking inside. Can't imagine it, if you only see the outside. Have hardly ever seen such a wonderful ceiling. We definitely recommend it.

Beautiful. It was one of the first churches we visited and it was very nice. they have a little museum you can visit to for an additional cost. If you are a woman, remember to where something appropriate otherwise they provide a while gauze material to cover yourself up with.

Beautiful church. We visited this church on the urging of family who live in Rome. It is a beautiful church to see. Make sure you cover your shoulders if you are a female, they are as strict as the Vatican.

Where was the point of light?. We went to this Basilica from the advice of a couple of American tourists that told us about Galileo designing the church where an aperture in the church ceiling at 12pm everyday the sun's light will shine through and point on the church floor the exact day/month/year. It was a cloudy day and we didn't see anything. We did get a chance to go again on the day of our departure. Cloudless day and full sunshine but still no point on the ground. Several people seemed to be aware of this fact as well. Other than that the basilica is pristine and beautiful with the art, sculptures and architecture. Definitely a must see if you're around Roma Termini.
Amazing sight. Dont miss this. It is free and the beauty of this Basilica can not be described. You are also allowed to take photos.

ight across from hotel palazzo rospiglioso. This church was closed most weekdays. When we finally did get inside it has amazing gold ceilings. Wear something that covers your shoulders or they won't let you in.

One of Many Beautiful Churches in Rome. You can easily get overwhelmed by the vast number of beautiful churches in Rome.This one is worth a quick visit, if time permits. The church contains a reliquary said to contain wood from the Holy Crib of the Nativity of Jesus.

beautiful. I went to Mass at this Basilica on the feast of Sts. Peter & Paul. It was a high mass, sung with a choir and orchestra, celebrated by a Cardinal and about 15 bishops. Was very impressive, even though all in Italian and Latin. Went back the next day to tour it.

Big and beautiful. Like the adjective "maggiore" suggests, this place is huge and the belltower is quite unusual. Very spaciuous inside and a cool place to hide from the heat. Great artworks, check out the capella Paolina.

Beautiful basilica. I went to Mass at this Basilica on the feast of Sts. Peter & Paul. It was a high mass, sung with a choir and orchestra, celebrated by a Cardinal and about 15 bishops. Was very impressive, even though all in Italian and Latin. Went back the next day to tour it.

Beautiful church worth a visit. We enjoyed our visit here. It is one of the oldest churches in Rome According to Wikipedia ...."Landmark papal basilica founded in the 5th century & known for its Roman mosaics & gilded ceiling."
Watch your purse, one of the participants in a baptism had their purse stolen while we were there.

Stunning. It's jaw droppingly beautiful
Don't forget to cover shoulders and knees

Another amazing catholic basilica. It would just be unforgivable to visit Rome without going to this basilica, it is almost as imposing as st. Peter's basilica, with amazing marble decor, Bernini designed beautiful stairs and imposing design. It is at walking distance from the railway station and is surrounded by many good eatalian eateries, it is open untill 19:00 hrs, a nice end of the day activity.
Mosaics look like they have been done yesterday. The mosaics in this church - with gold from the new found land - are in extremely good state - well done.
Beautiful. Well worth the look especially to appreciate the use of coloured marble in the architecture. Easily located and free entry.

Very beautiful!. Attended a morning mass on Saturday in the smaller side chapel - a wonderful experience. The Basilica is amazing. It was interesting to see the confessional rooms lining the outside of the main church - each confessional booth accommodated a different language! There is a gift shop (almost all of the churches we visited had them) with informational books. The architecture and the artifacts are amazing!!

S M M. This basillica is one of my favorite spots in whole of Rome! A MUST see! Really beautiful mosaics inside and the outside is nice too. It is close to Termini station, so, even if you are just a few hours in Rome, stuck in Termini, go and see it!
Small and just beautiful. This is worth a 1 hour visit. There are fewer crowds however no less beautiful than the Vatican. Good access from the hop on hop off bus.

Shocked at how great this was. We popped in here one evening while out for a stroll, not realizing haw amazing this church was. Fabulous frescos, and really a stunning church in a town with many amazing churches. Well worth the visit, and check out the neighboring basilica while you are there.

One of Rome's great churches. This church is hard to love at first. It's huge, it's hard to see the mosaics, and it's full of religious pilgrims. But that's part of what makes the church special--most of the visitors are religious visitors, so there's less of the tourist madness that infects St. Peter's. The mosaics--both the older, Early Christian nave mosaics and the "newer" Torritti mosaics in the apse--are extraordinary. I particularly love the museum, where you can see a reliquary with the hair of the Virgin Mary (!) and Arnolfo di Cambio's presepio or manger scene.
Beautiful church. The artwork is amazing and it is a quick stop so if you can fit in 15-20 minutes you should visit just to see the amazing architecture and art inside.
IMHO.... It's kinda famous. You're bright people, am sure you'll figure it all out with a guide book and all.

Beautiful surprise. We walked by this Basilica not having heard of it and wandered in. What a surprise! Do no skip this beautiful treasure. Reminded me of St. Peter's. One of my favorite places we visited in Rome.

One of my faves. It can be challenging to pick just one church or basilica that is the most stunning when you're in a place like rome, and whereas this was a truly stunning church it actually tops my list for a slightly different reason. While my friend and I were in the church there was a service going on in one of the chapels and when the choir started to sing there was something inherently beautiful of being in such a truly stunning church while listening to a choir. It left me absolutely in awe. And whether you are religious or not, its hard not feel the spirit while listening. Overall though a truly lovely church.

Beautiful, BUT..... I was torn. As a tourist and a general observer, I thought the basilica was absolutely beautiful. My wife especially enjoyed the golden ceilings. The mosaics around the place were gorgeous, too. However, as devout Christians, we were a little appalled. Our biggest gripe with the place could be summed up by asking a single question - where was Jesus in this place?A tip for the ladies is to remember - just as you as you should remember when visiting any of the other Roman basilicas - be sure to have your knees and shoulders covered upon entry. It's hit or miss if anyone will say anything to you.

Best church in Rome. For all the people who love churches and their architecture:Thats the place for u!!The whole ceiling is covered with an adorable gold muster In between are paintings and great pics of saints and bible storiesThere is also a chamber downstairs where u can see a big statue of a kneeling man who is praying and e few more thingsEverything is free to enter
Old School Catholic. Going to Mass here is like going back before the Second Vatican Council make changes. A step back in history of the Church.

Beautiful mosaics. The art in this church is amazing. The church itself is a little uninspired, however, and the art is not as easy to see as in other churches, such as the Ecstasy of St. Teresa in the Santa Maria della Vittoria. If you happen to be in the neighborhood and have the time, definitely worth a visit.

More than meets the eye. This church can be easily missed. From the outside, it does not even begin to suggest the beauty inside. The art and mosaic span a wide period and are all worth time spent. The mosaic are spectacular and charming. Don't be misled by the modest exterior.
Mosaics. Just do not miss... There is also another church 2 blocks over with even older mosaics. Look at the floors, the chapels and antiquity. It is an amazing bascilica (one of the 4 majors).

Church only so-so, but the mosaics are stunning!. You will have to pay a few Euros to light up the mosaics, but it is worth it. These are the oldest known Christian mosaics and they are stunning. Unfortunately, they are up very high so it is a bit hard to see--but worth a slight detour if you have the time. Entrance is free, but you have to pay for the lights--or wait for someone else to do it.

Beautiful and Interesting. Visited here early on Sunday, stayed for the Mass, then toured the museum underneath, many religious paintings and ancient church vestments, jewelled chalices. Well worth a visit.

Amazing Basilica. No queues and just wall to wall stunning paintings, frescos, mosaics and sculptures in this amazing Roman Church that we walked past every day until we chanced a look inside. Amazing!

Cute. It was one of the last churches I've visited in Rome, so after seeing so many beautiful churches in one trip, it seemed kinda average in comparison. If you're in the area, drop by, but it's not a must-see landmark.

So Beautiful. It was truly remarkable. It's history is very interesting. The building is so peaceful. The only thing we didn't like you are asked not to take photographs and so many people ignored this.

A must see landmark. We visitied the Basilica on our way from Terminin Station to Colosseum. Located in a relatively quiet part of Rome, it is within walking distance from both. Those who like architecture can admire a variety of styles and the imposing interior. Women wearing shorts or sleevless top are required to veil themselves. Disposable veils are provided on site.

my last hour in rome. In my last hour before the airport bus I knew there was only one place I still wanted to see. I had past many times but never been in. So I ran 4 blocks on a sunny sunday morning. It was the special day of the poor. It was a delight to sit here and reflect on my italy trip and admire this beautiful building. Just then the choir started singing. I couldnt see where they were. I truly felt blessed sitting there.only 3 blocks from termini and open 7am to 7pm every day.
lovely chapel. A beautiful church, nearly as interesting as the Basilica of St. Peter's. A lot of beautiful artwork, frescoes and other wonderful artifacts.
A must see!. The basilica is very beautiful. The art is amazing. It is one of the largest churches and a must see for everyone.

Nice. Maybe this church is the only "must see" in the neighborhood of Roma Termini. I liked both the exterior and the interior of Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore. We visited it very early in the morning, before we took the bus to the airport and it was the best way to say "Arrivederci Roma"!
Great church!. A must see, the church is just overwhelming. We saw mass on a Sunday and it was an great service. A must go to location.

Definitely worth a visit. This is a beautiful Basilica in a more quiet area of town. Luck had it that we were staying in a hotel very close by. The only drawback is you have to wade past the people trying to sell you stuff. A polite no worked, but there were so many of them. The Basilica I believe was much more appealing than the Vatican. It was just beautiful inside and out.

Beautiful, quiet and a nice place for a short respite. Located near Termini Station and the many lodgings in the area, this magnificent church is well worth a visit. We visited it twice-once to view the marvelous structure and again to take a short respite during our day of walking around Rome. It is air conditioned and the church is filled with music at times. There is a small bookstore within the facility and nice WC's available if needed. It is free and cameras are allowed. (Note to Trip Advisor editors: I accidentally reviewed the attica s. Maggiore as the Basilica-please delete)

a real Roman Catholic Basilica. you can feel that faith is still very alive here. And please have a look at the floor and the magnificent ceiling. I visited this basilica 3 times during my stay. It gives a feeling of being very welcome
Beautiful mosaics. A very big church,the largest church in Rome dedicated to the Virgin Mary.The campanile(bell tower) is the highest in Rome-about 75 m.Beautiful mosaics inside.

A stunning treasure in Rome. An overwhelming artistic and historic experience. Second only to St. Peters in its significance. Several Popes are buried here among beautiful murals, intricate mosaics, sculpture, overwhelmingly beautiful alcoves.

One of the best. A little out of the way compared to the rest of Rome's most famous sites but well worth a visit, this is a very large basilica lots of fantastic murals and art. They also let you look around areas other basilicas don't and there are some very interesting nooks and crannies

Santa Maria Maggiore: a sense of the sacred. Our first family experience of the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore was a divine Christmas Midnight Mass many years ago. This year, as a couple, we made a nostalgic re-visit and discovered that the exterior might have grown a little more tired but inside, Santa Maria Maggiore remains one of Rome's foremost churches. With its papal tombs, Baroque interior, 5th century mosaics, amazing paving, 12th-13th century "Madonna and Child" above the altar, a bell tower in the Romanesque style, a sense of the sacred is assured.
A find. We only found this whilst waiting for the sightseeing bus. Is very impressive and worth a visi. OK in Rome you MUST visit St Peters but this is a close second
Awe inspiring. Absolutely a beautiful church. My wife called it "like being inside a Faberge egg." The artwork was amazing. The history of the church was very interesting.

Rome is the place for amazing churches!. We love churches, cathedrals, basilicas, etc., for their religious significance and history, but also for their amazing architecture. We were lucky enough to attend mass while visiting the Basilica, which really gave us an opportunity to appreciate it. Well worth the stop!

Stunning church!. I went to Santa Maria Maggiore just when I felt "churched-out"I I am without words to express the beauty of its interior. The intricate gold-plated ceiling alone is enough to justify a visit. The crypt in marble, with a life-size statue of Pius IX in prayer before the altar of the Madonna is richly decorated. This huge church is a hidden gem that doesn't always figure on the route of most tours. Don't let that stop you, just go there. You won't regret it!

Santa Maria maggiore. We hadn't planned to visit this church during our stay but since it was close to the hotel and it was raining we went in. What a great place. Well worth the visit.Reputed to hold parts of the original manger, but not on show

Beautiful and monumental. This church has been one block away from our hotel near Termini station. It has a beautiful outlook, it's very monumental. There is a big square before it which would be suitable for farmer's market or something similar however, it is totally used for nothing. If you are around the place, you should definitely have a look. Otherwise it is not so special to be visited from the other side of the city.

A sight that takes your breath away. While this is a bit of a walk, and a little hard to find on the map. When you get into the church, it will make you stop and gasp. The ceiling, the paintings, the different smaller chapels where services were taking place were gorgeous. Go sit on a bench, you'll marvel at the beauty.

Basilica. This is certainly worth the visit. Very spectacular!We got there and saw a very long lineup and thought we are here so we may as well wait in line.To out surprise, it only took about 20 to 25 minutes to get into the church. You can take a guided tour or go through the Sistine Chapel at your own leisure which we did. You don't have to be Catholic to thoroughly enjoy. Allow yourself at least 3 hours to go through everything.The Church is free but there is a fee for the Sistine Chapel.
Excellent Example of Basilica in Rome. Beautiful. I would have liked to have attended mass, but time did not permit. While in the area, the Pope made an appearance.

Piece of art. It was a walking distance from my hotel.The facade is interesting. The interior is low lighted; vast spaces, wall & roof paintings, statues & numerous chapels.Crowded place; but worth visiting.
important visit. Since many years I promess me to visit this monumentI am very pleased to visit this place on Rome and I should like to visit again next year

Unbelievably Beautiful. This church is so beautiful. We just couldn't believe all of the beautiful paintings and detail that went into creating this church. It was one of the first churches we visited on our trip to Italy and it is still one of our favorites.

Unexpected good experience. We had no plan to go the the basilica, until we passed by and decided to go in. It is definitely worth to pay a visit. We were surprised how magnificent inside of the basilica is. It's free when we went there. I think it's even nicer than some other cathedrals or churches require entrance fee. Highly recommended!
Basilica. Lots of construction when we there so we did not go in. Nice neighborhood. Great restaurants. Beautiful looking building.

another must see. This is a stately church, full of recycled Roman columns and of artistic treasures. I visited it several times and it was never crowded. It has a lovely luminosity because it is so open and uncluttered. It is very different style from St Peter's or St Giovanni in Laterano, one which may be closer to the original ancient form.
Beautiful basilica. A not to be missed extremely impressive active church in central Rome. Awe inspiring site especially on Sunday morning when masses are ongoing.
Worth a visit. Yes, there are lots of basilicas to visit in Rome. This one is absolutely worth a stop if you have the time,

Superb art and beautiful architecture. Difficult to overstate the beauty of this basilica. A bit out of the way from the rest of Rome's main tourist spots, but close to Termini Station, so not difficult to reach. Don't miss it! The rows of huge columns and large number of superb paintings are not to be missed. As mentioned by others, it's good to bring your own guidebook or information, as there's little or no descriptions of what you are seeing in languages other than Italian.

Lovely church shame there were no information signs. Worth a visit but see if you can download an audio guide. Rated average as like majority places of interest in Rome, they have made no effort to put up information signs about things you are looking at. It can't be too difficult to use google translate or other to provide information in say 6 main languages with the numbers of tourists that visit. The guide books on Rome give some information but not enough for each site so you need more and in Rome this has to be at a cost as they take the opportunity to get you to pay for every little thing as an add on!!

A lot to look at here, well worth a visit. You can spend a lot of time here, there are various styles of art inside. We went in June and there were no crowds, good gift shop, lovely courtyard, something for everyone.

WOW.... simply beautiful. We stayed in Rome for 2 days at the end of Italian holiday and we were on a hop on hop off bus and it passed this church and said it claims to have the timber from the manger of christ.Well I will say that during our holiday around Europe we have been through many many churches but none left us so touched and moved as this one did. There is no queues or admission fares to get in, it is simply open to the public with out grand claims or fuss.Im not here to say if it is or isn't what they claim but the spirituality and the presentation of its claim is so very moving and touching, so much so it left us speechless for hours and would have had to have been one of our most memorable places of our holiday.Take time to see this beautiful and simple church and feel its spirit.

Huge church with a lot of art inside. The basilica located not far from the terminal station, do not have to be missed.
It has an impressive outside but the inside is even more interesting with lots of sculptures and paintings.
The only problem is that it is always very crowded what makes it hard to enjoy it.

Absolutely beautiful!. We visited this Basilica as the last on a tour of the major basilicas of the Vatican. This one was probably the most "real" do the the three. It is obviously used as a regular Catholic church, like all of them, but it felt like it was more than a museum. It contains a relic from The manager of Christ; it is placed beneath the altar. If you are Catholic, make sure that you see the major Basilicas in addition to those in the Vatican state. This one is also part of the Vatican, as are St. Paul's and St. John's cathedrals. These ones are not heavily busy with tourists, making them a respite after touring the Vatican.
So beautiful !. It was simply movingEverywhere you look there is beauty! If you want to see more about popes through the gift shop you can get to the museum.

Nice outside, beautiful inside. We were in the Mecenate Palace across the square. We had a view of this Basilica from both our room and the terrace of the hotel. We organised a number of tours, but were knew we couldn't miss looking in here before leaving. We weren't disappointed. The interior is quite striking. To my surprise the there was another Sistine Chapel in Rome! There are many mosaics (if that's your thing). The Pauline chapel was in use during our visit, but looks very interesting. There are too many places of interest inside to list in this review. So I suggest you visit for yourself, you won't be disappointed either...
Fantastic. This was one of my favourite churches, breath taking, not packed like some of the other sites. You could just sit and take in the beauty of the place!!

Beautiful Basilica. It is part way between a Metro Station and the hotel where we were staying so we passed it often. It is quite large and impressive inside with its marble work and statues. Different from St Peter's in that there are not the large number of visitors St Peters has but it also does not contain the same number of historical paintings and relics. As a result it is a lot quieter and serene. Less than one hour is required to see everything.

Marble Galore. Beautiful church. Warmer than the St. Peter's. The multi-colored marble is gorgeous. TIP: Go very early in the morning. The church opens at 7AM and visiting it while it is empty is a treat.

Impressive. Large, impressive and very much still used as an active Catholic Church. Not being catholic I was fascinated by the wooden confession 'huts' with red lights lit up on the top when their was a priest available. Stunning marble and detailed wall religious art.
Very grand. It's a typical display of wealth that all Rome's churches have. I suggest if you've travelled vie the Termini, make it your first, or last place to visit, as its 5 minutes away.
An interesting Church. Rome is full of churches & this one is interesting & stands out compared to some others. Also it's on the tour bus route so very easy to get to.

Huge - Stunning - but Dark on a wet day. This is on the must see list in Rome, and it is quite the stunning basilica. Unfortunately it was pouring buckets when we visited, and the inside is not well lit. We could not make out the mosaics - but the crypt with the kneeling pope is well worth the wander in to view.

Not as grand as some of the other basilicas...but worth the time!. This church is lovely....it is also on the "get on-hop off" bus route, so easy enough to access. It looks quite unassuming from the outside, but that makes the discovery of its wonder inside that much better. It is full of amazing art work and statues...and even what my friend (a practicing catholic) called 'a pickled pontiff'....laying in a casket. Aside from that, it is a spectacular example of over the top churches...and one of my favorite discoveries in Rome.
Wow and something finally free. What a lovely place and for Rome something actually free which is unheard off . The architecture is lovely and different
you must lok at this. you hear a lot about all the famous places but give this a try. Very peaceful and some lovely paintings and thinks to see. Give it a go

Full of History. This is one of the most beautiful churches in entire Rome. The holy church in honor of the Holy Mary is one of the Mayor Basilicas and part of the Pentarquia of the Patriarch. The church does not collect any entry fee (it does accept donations in the boxes at the entrance) and would allow entry only to people that is covering the shoulders and legs (they will give you something to cover otherwise). The design and decorations inside are unique. There is a lot of history within this walls and its important to do some research before going to know what are you looking at. You would see the sanctuaries of 3 popes, a statue with the remains of the cradle of Christ and a lot of very famous pictures and statues. Its very close to Termini train station so would be close for sure so take a few minutes to look inside and enjoy!! its worth it!

What a view. Our hotel was directly opposite this, so we had a wonderful view. This is an amazing building, full of very elaborate architecture. Busy. Make sure you have a scarf with you to cover your shoulders if you are a women however they do supply cover-ups if needed.

Must visit place in Rome. From a Christian perspective, it was a spiritual experience. There are many priests stand by ready to listen to your confession. It feels very refreshing afterward. I am glad this is my first stop my first in Rome. I felt very refreshing. I could feel Our Lady's presence.

"Beautiful Church". This beautiful church was a short walk from our hotel and not far from the train station. It is definitely worth seeing and one of the musts when visiting Rome. It is being renovated and you can only get in through certain doors. There are some great mosaics and lots of marble. Lovely music was being played softly. Nice gift shop for religious articles.

One of our favorite Basillica's. We really enjoyed this Basillica. It is beautiful both inside and out. It has an interesting piece of art history in that there is a fresco in there that depicts the moon as described by Galileo after his viewing it with a telescope - painted by a friend of his WHILE Galileo was being prosecuted by the church. This Basillica is full of wonderful stories like that and wonderful art as well.
One of the Great Churches in Rome. For sheer size and wow factor, Maria Maggiore is hard to beat! This church predates St. Peter's and has signs commemorating all the Popes who visited there.
very interesting. Excellent guide around the basement and the upstairs. a lift to the top which was great for me. Beautiful architecture.

Stunning. I can't believe that places like this are free to enter! The interior of this basilica is stunning. I'd recommend buying a guide book. There's a marble walled room down some stairs near the altar. In it is a silver container that apparently has parts of Jesus' manger within. I'm not religious at all, but was quite taken with this building & even gave it a second visit.

Wonderful Papal Basilica. While there are many beautiful basilicas in Rome, Santa Maria Maggiore is certainly one of the largest and most uniquely decorated as a papal basilica. In addition to extravagant marble, there are some beautiful mosaics lining the nave. It might be difficult for some tourists to get to because it can be a little bit of a walk (or a bus ride) depending on where one is staying as it is near termini station.
beautiful. Really beautiful inside, a must when visiting rome.easy walk from cavour metro station and nice cafes nearby to get a coffee after.
Beatiful church. Liked it all, disliked nothing. Marvellous coffered ceiling and such a contrast between the exterior building and the interior.

Beautiful Church. One of the beautiful churches in Rome. We visited the church in the afternoon hours and there were few visitors. This magnificent church is located a few blocks from the Opera theater.
One of the many must seen in Rome. One of the many must seen in Rome. Centuries of art history at your fingertips. The floor design is breath taking.

A must see basilica in the heart of rome. Thanks to other Tripadvisor reviews we made a point of including this basilica in our itinerary and it did not disappoint. Intricate frescoes, beautiful statues, chapels for saints and impressive architecture. We took the train from termini and walked to the basilica which is located on a busy intersection. The main altar within the church is impressive as well as the labyrinth right below the altar which has a huge life size marble carving of the pope in a prayerful pose. Architecturally satisfying and spiritually fulfilling this is a beautiful church for mother Mary. Apparently the only church in Rome outside the vatican walls that is managed by the Vatican -and it is well maintained.There is a small gift shop at the side exit from the church where I purchased some beautiful gifts/ momentos .

Most beautiful church we found in Rome (outside of the Vatican). What a pleasant surprise! We went to the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore on a recommendation from the front desk of our hotel as a church for mass on Sunday.
