But in addition to mass (this is an active church), we were treated to the most beautiful church we saw during our trip to Rome, Florence, and Venice.It is only a short walk from either the Repubblica or Termini red metro stops, and even closer to the Cavour blue metro stop.You will want to reserve at least a half hour to appreciate the artwork and architecture and the side library that this church has to offer. I don't want to over-sell it, but this church is beautiful. It is not as big as the Duomo in Florence, but it is every bit a magnificent inside.I do not know if there is a cost to enter (there probably is), but we did not have to pay since we went for mass on Sunday

holy crib reliquary. This was the last church we visited in Rome before we took off for Florence. Large, and full of the architectural features we have come to expect in Rome, it was a fitting finale when we saw the beautiful silver/gold reliquary displaying a piece from the holy crib!

Beautiful. Second only to Saint peter's, beautiful church to visit.
However the Santa Maria near the Piazza del popolo was also an unexpected succes.

Close to termini. This church is short walk from termini or first stop on sight seeing buses. Free to have walk round inside. My friend even went to mass on a monday morning.
Really nicevto look around.
Beautiful building lit up at night
Beautiful. The size, the beauty, Michelangelo design and Caravaggio paintings. Just brilliant. Free to enter, stand in the middle to gauge the beauty.

An absolute must see. An architectural 4th century masterpiece. Stunning and not crowded at all. Just make sure you dress respectfully. No shorts, singlet tops nor thongs. Easy walk from main train station and it was free entry. There are parts of Jesus's crib downstairs and the ceiling is breathtaking.

A real tourist hot spot, but well worth it.. A wonderful building. The decoration is overwhelming. It can be very busy but it is one of the churches you must visit if you can only do a couple while visiting.. Great at epiphany.

Real Peace. The Satue Di Santa Maria infront Of The Church Is só Real And Beautiful I could not tale My Eyes Off.
The Church hás só much beauty words cannot express just contemplate all,brings Innerpeace and no One can speak or take all Inn the reality of all around us.Is a never end reality Of a Christian City.

Wonderful experience. On the Saturday (May 10, 2014) we were there, a beautiful wedding was taking place. I can't think of a more beautiful place to get married than this basilica.
There are many churchs in Rome but this one is worth taking time to visit.
Beautiful church. Beautiful church with an ornate ceiling. Highly recommended if you have the time. It should only take about 1 hour to visit.

Absolutely Stunning. Our hotel was directly across from this Basilica and we enjoyed wonderful views of it day and night. Since we were so close we had ample opportunity to pay a visit to this very beautiful Basilica on several occasions over the eight days we stayed in Rome. I found myself drawn to go back time and time again just to memorize more of the beauty inside. Very peaceful, a magnificent work of architectural beauty.

Great place but beware of opening hours. This is a beautiful church with two Caravaggios, but it only opens a few hours am and 4 to 7pm. Once inside there is a nazi that screams Silenzio! If you dare to talk while he lights candles and rearranges the furniture. Be quiet so the Italians can scream.

One of the four Catholic churches that every pilgrim to Rome should visit. We came here as we had read that there were four Catholic churches that every pilgrim to Rome should see.
Of these four, all of which we saw, this was the one that I liked the least.
The architecture is stunning however, the atmosphere of the church was not as great as the others we saw.
Gorgeous basilica. Brilliant! What did you like about it? So gorgeous inside- one of the most beautiful basilicas we visited- so peaceful, located near other interesting sites as well.
Stunning. We stayed at the Rafaello Hotel which was just down the street from this beautiful Basilica. The paintings on the ceilings are incredible. Highly recommend a visit if your time allows.

Mosaics Line the Nave. Nice church with some of Rome's best preserved mosaics lining the nave. Built as Rome was falling. Chapels in the transepts are very lovely.
A pair of small binoculars to view the mosaics is useful.
If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

Should be on your short list. One of the best churches in Rome and when there ask about the museum under the church which was 3 euro p.p. to enter. Very worth it in time and price yet few people seemed aware of its existence.

Do not miss this one. There is a legend that there was snow in Rome in August at place where the church know stands. Every 5th August they send out flowers from the loggia to memorate this. Bernini is burried here, the marvellous Borghese chapel where the little sister of Napoleon is burried adorned with lapiz lauzuli and other precious stones. The crypt in polyform maarble where the pope in marble is praying and the epitaphium of Antonio near the bookshop and much more is there to see inside the church.

Beautiful. Take time to linger here. We bought a lemon gelato from the vendor in the piaxza and sat in the shade on the steps. Afterwards, we strolled inside this church with gilded ceiling, stained glass, murals, and marble. Gorgeous!
Beautiful. If you like to see churches and basilicas you cannot miss the beauty found here. We were in awe of how spectacular the inside was. We were happy to have have seen it.
Beautiful Church. Very handy location and an amazing building well worth a visit en route to Colosseum - very popular and a hidden extra
Absolutely Magnificent!. One of the best places of worship we have ever visited! Beautiful interior - takes your breath away.
Beautiful!. Hotel Martini is only a 5min walk to this Basilica. We watched Sunday mass, and visited the whole Basilica as it was so beautiful, and amazing architecture.
wonderful church. Like a mini St Peters, breathtaking decoration in a large church. good value and a must visit if in the vicinity

Magnificent!. Where to start.
Despite its central location, it's not too busy, has magnificent decoration and we were even in the building when Pope Francis arrived for private prayer!
Don't miss it!

Exquisite!. In my opinion from a religious architectural point of view the most beautiful. Is also probably the smallest. Very beautiful with a lot of biblical details gives you the impression of being in a temple. The walls are beautiful and the altar as well. Provokes a deep sense of worship.

Holy Crib. This grand Papal Basilica captivates you with its exterior and interior. First and foremost relic of the church is the Reliquary of the Holy Crib in the crypt of Nativity. Little Bethlehem of Europe !!!
well located. Roma has many Churchs, some are not seen as Saint Pietro Cathedral, but they are in as much as magnific as the worldwide knowed, try to go and pay attention on the roof (gorgeous)

Amazing... This one gives Sistine Chapel a run for the money. From The outside it is greater and the inside is Amazing. Inside there is a great many columns and great murals inside. Like all churches in Rome, what is there is see is just a look above.
Magnificent. The sculptures are breath-taking The setting is lovely. The timed tickets are a smart way to serve the crowds. Be sure you get a reservation in advance.

Magnificent. Truly an understated jewel of the city! It has beautiful mosaic flooring, the frescos on the ceilings, the sculptures, the reliquary with the remnants of the holy manger....the list goes on. It is still an active church with locals coming to worship regularly, as well. To witness this worship and celebration, complete with the singing voices is truly inspiring. You will not be disappointed making a visit here. Please remember to be respectful of those there to worship. As I mentioned, it is after all a church. My only disappointment was the embarrassment I felt for those visitors that did not treat it as such.

Absolutely Lovely. By far one of the best things to see while in Rome. If you approach from the backside of the church you'll say not worth going in. BUT once you get to the front, and actually go in, you'll be glad you did.

Beautiful experience. I felt very privilidge to join a polish mass on one of my random walking trips around Rome. As a polish traveller-Christian it was amazing to be part of the service in this stunning church

Wow. 1st time visiting this church and blessed to enter it.All I can say is Wow, thank you Lord for giving me the opportunity to visit this church. Church is just walking distance to Termini station. Also, near the Church of St. Alphonsus via Merulana (the location of original painting of Our Mother of Perpetual Help), and walking distance (15 minutes) to St. John de Lateran (via Merulana).

Great church!. This church is beautiful inside and out. The architecture is amazing! You will find wood remnants of the Holy Crib of the nativity of Jesus Christ inside a reliquary. Be sure to walk around back and get a view of the basilica while standing by the obelisk.
Magnificent experience!. We have visited this church before, but it seemed worth it to pay another visit and we did not regret doing so. It is well done with interesting architecture.
Hidden Gem. Well worth the visit, absolutely moving. Very special Vatican church, the religious experience was incredible

An Unassuming Plain White Wrapper. I am guilty of passing this artistic gem by on my way to Ancient Rome many times. Fortunately, my wife suggested we stop in; we were very well rewarded by the art and the architecture. As this is a Basilica, there is the seemingly mandatory lead and glass chamber with a silver death mask and papal robes. Don't forget to express your appreciation to Bernini, as he is still there!P.S. The sit down gelateria across Via Gilberto to the east was not worth braving the Italian traffic.

Be sure to walk all the way around the church. This is one of the most ancient and greatest basilicas in Rome and you have to see it from all sides to truly appreciate its majesty. Along the front there is a Corinthian column and a fountain. Around the back, an Egyptian obelisk and double domes. Inside, every bit of wall is covered with rich sculptures, paintings and frescoes. A particularly ornate one is to the Sistine Chapel (not to be confused with the one in the Vatican) that is the first chapel on the right. The first time we visited it was closed but the second time we were lucky to get in. The mosaic in the apse dates back to 1295 and the one in the triumphal arch to the 5th century. Take your time to look closely at all the art work.

Beautiful Basilica. I love going to Italy and seeing all the beautiful churches, duomos and basilicas. They are all so spectacular. The Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore is stunning. The art work and details of the ceiling are really impressive.

Daily Mass. We stayed at the Augusta Lucilla Palace and walked to daily morning mass in the Pauline Chapel. It was joyfully distracting to be surrounded by the beauty and see the bronze relief of Our Lady of Snow. Bernini's tomb with the words "... humbly rests: was especially moving after seeing his amazing art throughout the city. The couple that staff the gift shop were very helpful and friendly. My mother picked up all of her religious gifts there.

BASILICA DI SANTA MARIA MAGGIORE. If you are interested in Churches this is one to visit. Its ornate ceiling is magnificent. Many people just go in to the Church to sit for a while or even to read in the wonderful ambience.

Stunning. Your eyes are drawn to all parts of this church including the doors as you enter. A feeling of sepulchral calm pervades the whole atmosphere and we took the opportunity to sit and wonder at the building surrounding us. We didn't realise how long it took for us to look at everything. Of particular interest is the small chapel under the main altar, where the relic of the crib is displayed. The array of different marbles is breathtaking. There is a chapel to the right of the main altar which has beautiful frescoes and ceiling. The only downside was the prayer "candles" - you were invited to insert a coin which activated a timer for an electric candle! Nevertheless, a stunning experience.
What an amazing place. We almost missed it. At first we though one more church but it was very special. The ceiling was amazing. It had a reverent feeling.
Impressive. Very close to hotel. Location in movie DaVinci's Code. Made us come home to watch movie again to see different locations in Rome.

Second only to St. Peter's...stunning. This basilica is probably the closest to the Termini station, being only a few blocks away. At first impression, you would probably walk by and think nothing of it for this beautiful church hides all of its glory indoors. However, it is worth and stop to enjoy just how magnificent it is indoors. As with all of the churches, it is free and the decor is beautiful. Enjoy a slow walk through all of the little alcoves to truly enjoy all it has to offer. There is a small museum and gift shop and clean restrooms just outside the gift shop. It is an easy walk from the Monte area so if you are staying near the termini station, you will not want to miss this church. The nearest metro station is the termini station.

Great church. Very serene even with tourists going in and out and snapping pictures. Beautiful church. Takes a while to walk around and see everything. You can even light a candle and say a prayer. Worth a visit.
beautiful church. like majority of the churches in Rome, just beautiful. I would recommend a day where you visit churches in Rome. You will not be dissappointed. It's FREE.

A breathtaking Basilica. Churches in Rome are free and nearly always open to the public. Santa Maria is one of the four Vatican churches and important to the city's culture and history. The interior is incredible to look at and pictures are allowed in most parts of the church. Just keep in mind it is a place of worship so be respectful to others and wear modest clothing if you plan to visit.
Beautiful church and beautiful view. We took the bus to the church and enjoyed the ride and we got pleasure out of entering the church. It is probably the most impressive view of Rome possible.

Not too impressive. Maybe I am not religious, I found it ordinary. Compared to many other churches, this doesn't impress me. Also outside the church there are many seedy people around, the smell of urine, the dirty square disgust me
Atmospheric. We stayed at a hotel only a few hundred yards away it is a beautiful building and we also attended Sunday service which was very moving, visitors also encouraged to take communion

Church of Santa Maria Maggiore. Only second to St. Peter's Basilica. Don't miss the remains of Christ's crib downstairs. Also visit the museum downstairs outside the church. Don't eat near the Basilica as the restaurants are tourist traps.

Santa Maria Maggiore. On the way back to the Termini train station, I decided to visit this church. After you climb a wide staircase, you'll see on your right a statue of Philip the 4th, former King of Spain. Like most churches, there is no admission fee to get in. Once you pass the big door, you'll see a majestic church with a big central nave and two side naves separates by columns. On the sides there are some chapels. In one of them they were celebrating a mass and no pictures were allowed. It is a quite humbling experience to visit such a beautiful church. There are very old mosaics and beautiful paintings with religious subjects. There is art from its construction, centuries ago, to more modern one, like a museum where new art is regularly added without removing the old one. This church is dedicated to the Virgin Mary, so most of the art is about her. Each pope added something either modifying the existing structure or either building a new part. The golden ceiling was added later for instance. The central altar is raised and on the bottom floor there is a statue of a pope praying in front of what is said to contain a relic of the wood of the crib where Jesus was born. There is really a lot to see to be described in a review, so I suggest you spend more than an hour here.

A church in Rome where Christianity still lives. We visited a lot of churches in Rome, most visitors are picture taking tourists while few praying people can be seen. In this basilic many of the visitors where actually people who came to pray in one of the many chapels.

Beautiful and serene. This church is so beautiful - really comparable to the Vatican in my opinion. How the artists were able to accomplish the work is just beyond imagining. It is still a church used for services today.

Many altars. This church was so beautiful. There were so many altars and so much art. They had confessions in several different languages, including English. There was a mass going on and I even got to go to communion. The music was lovely. Worth seeing.
Divine. Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore is a must-see church where you can both feel connection with the Christian world and admire the perfect beauty of its mosaics, frescoes and the altar.
Stunning!. Found this place by accident but what a gem! We enjoyed the stunning views, art and architecture. Right in the middle of avarything.

Stunning. We stayed in the Mecenate Palace Hotel with views of this beautiful church. A fantastic example of Rome's finest and a must see if you are into your churches (my husband and I are not the least bit religious but this is a wonderful place). Add it to the list !!
Wow. If you like churches, this is one of the top ten in Rome. (There are hundreds) Descriptions are useless, either see them if you like them or don't
The most beautiful church in Rome. I visited quite a number of churches in Rome.... and this is the most beautiful one. Definitely not to be missed.

Very big and very beautiful. Add very tasteful. In most cities, this would be a first day activity. In Rome, this is a day 3 activity, but if you don't have a 3rd day, try to squeeze it in day 2. It's worth it.If you do go here, go to Santa Prassede, almost next door. I would also walk over to St Peter in Vincoli.

Stunning mosaics. This church has lovely mosaic lining its walls. On the right side of the nave, the mosaics tell the story of Moses. These are some of the best preserved mosaics. The mosaics in the apse are also stunning. Buy light (which last about 2 minutes) to light up these parts to truly be amazed. Lesser known to many, the tomb of Bernini lays in this basilica.

As impressive as always. I have been here before but this cathedral is as impressive as ever. From the physical structure to the artwork to the relics it is always memorable. A must see for anyone visiting Rome

TOO much to handle... Now I know why THIS is the place Pope Francis siad his first mass at POPE! It's phenomenally gorgeous.. and it opens our eyes to the MANY basilicas to visit. And here we only thought St. Peter's was the place to see! There are over 300 incredible churches in Rome. The entire city is a sacred treasure!!
Roma trip. Beautiful church and lovely to wander round with having touts trying sell tours. Very close to Termini Station so easy to find. Also accessible from from the hop on and off bis

A real treasure, above all the ancient mosaics!. The Santa Maria Maggiore "basilica" is surely something huge and astonishingly full of treasures showing all the layers of history that went through it, but what I definitely find the best gems of the church are the wonderful, very old mosaics – of the Fifth century! - at which you can take a glance from the pictures here on this site, either the ones up the two full sides of the main nave or the ones on the wall above the altar, on the triumphal arch (these ones even better!).About it, I feel to give everybody two tips to better appreciate the visit: 1) before all, obviously take your time to look at them carefully because there are depicted, with astonishing skill, many stories form the Bible and there are among the firsts on the world relating to the Virgin Mary!2) remember, before going to Santa Maria Maggiore, to put together a good bunch of coins, if I’m not wrong the 1 Euro size, because the lights to enlighten the mosaics aren’t free! And unfortunately they do not last long, so if you want admire them with calm, you have to put several. Your luck could be being inside with other intersted tourists, such as it happened to me, so when I finished my money, I could exploit other people coins! This is also comfortable because the coin - machine is at the other end of the nave, near the entrance, so then you have almost to run if you want fully use the coins you spend!Eventually it’s also worth a look the central floor, a very ancient and well preserved medieval art craft.
Magnificent. Lovely church with very nice mosaics from the 5th century. It also has wood that is said to be from the crib of Jesus.
Impressive Marian temple. Yes, San Pedro and Saint Giovanni are maybe the most impressive, but this Marian center is also worth visiting. Do not miss it!

Very impressive church!. This was the first place we visited post checking into our hotel in Rome. Indeed a beautiful and serene church with intricate art and architecture. Very close to Battestini metro on the red line
Awesome!. Its a sensory overload in Rome - there was so many staggeringly beautiful places to see but this Church also stood out - both interior and exterior.

Impressive church. You can spend at least half an hour in this amazing church. The artwork, the paintings and the various atmospheric chapels who were at service during our visit were truly enchanting.

Beautiful Church. We visited this church as on of the stops of the Hop On Hop Off bus and we weren't disappointed. This church has a relic of the manger of Jesus. The interior of the church is absolutely beautiful. You won't be disappointed
Great. Worth the visit. All the bisilicas are so well decorated and you can spend hours looking at all the details.

Enchanting. If you visit Roma, do not miss this incredible site. There are many altars under one roof. My favorite is the last on the left done in 18K gold. When outside make sure to walk around to the back of the building where the most beautiful stairs lead up to the magical Basilica. This is a great place to snap a photograph. Why is this my favorite? I was lucky enough to get married here almost 50 years to the date that my parents did in 1957. I am blessed.
Astonishing. The interior is breathtaking. The mosaic, paintings and the atmosphere. One of the major Basilikas in Rome.

Beautiful church for quiet reflection . You don't need a particularly long time in here but it is a beautiful church with some amazing artwork. The ceiling is amazing. Definitely worth a visit as it's free to step inside.
Beautiful. This church was amazing too see>joust round the corner from hotel.Well worth a visit.Really nothing just very interesting.

A Beautiful Church for the Faithful. This is another church that one could easily walk by without being impressed. Go inside and you will be amazed. It's like being in a smaller St. Peters. It's very beautiful.
Worth the visit. Great basilica, part of the Vatican property, the biggest basilica dedicated to Santa Maria...a must see if you are in Rome
Not much to see. Not a great deal to see. My son was very upset as he is studying history and didn't like the fact that all the roman statues had been removed. It's free to go in so why not
Don't miss it near Termini!. another surprising church in Rome!it was a huge basilica with numerous details and a beautiful wooden ceiling.it's one of the oldest churches in Rome,don't miss it.

A Basilica not to miss on the Esquiline Hill. This is a place that has always drawn me back several times when I am in Rome.There is of course St Peter's and many other impressive churches, but St Mary Major is special. The mosaics, side chapels, huge ancient columns and marble floor all blend and fit together in a way some others do not. The atmosphere is always serene and welcoming.
Stunning. The basilica was gorgeous when we visited. There was a service being held in one of the smaller sections and it was interesting to listen while we wandered through the beautiful rooms.
Worth a look. Really pretty and nice. Its completely free and nit to far away from the colosseum. When you go in look at the detail of the room is beautiful and so detailed. Certainly worth a visit.
Quite a surprise. Looks like a ruin from the outside but takes your breath away when you walk in especially as it was Palm Sunday when we visited and there was a service on

Opulent, magnificent. Traveller tip- great toilets!. Wow! This place is astonishing. Grandiose gilded ceilings. Amazing paintings, it is certainly awe inspiring. The dome was so beautiful, and made necks ache trying to see everything.From a traveller point of view, there are few public toilets in rome, and whilst all cafés do have them, they can be pretty basic. These at Santa Maria magi ore were large, clean and sanitary. In our experience, the best in rome!I recommend visiting the church because it is amazing.

"Breathtaking...a Must See!". My husband & I wanted to visit this Basilicia when in Rome with our tour group traveling with Gate 1 Travel. We were on a break from our tour group and really wanted to visit this Basilica since it is where Bernini is buried. The amazing ceilings with its golden frescoes is absolutely breathtaking! The baldaquin altar is impressive as is the statue of a praying Pius IX. Be sure and take the time to see this Basilica but you can take photos but not with the flash.
Excellent. Beautiful inside, well worth visiting. Some wonderful painted ceiling art and statues. Very unassuming from the outside
disappointing. Look forward to seeing all the frescos but the lighting was so bad could not see any of them. Basilica for praying yes, but for art lovers disappointing

The All Seeing Eye. A modest monster - Maggiore - 'major'. A great altar, amazing ceiling paintings in the domed naives, but it was the gold painting of the 'All Seeing Eye' that really dominated the experience of this church over others. I always take joy in donating though the offertory, poor boxes or gift shops in these generous churches that don't charge entry.

Another beautiful church!. This one is near the Termini train station so very convenient to numerous hotels and to travelers on the move.
Beautiful.
Huge and magnificent. Windows, paintings, frescoes, magnificent ceilings and all to glorify God. What a place! This huge Basilica gives you a sense of awe and wonder.

Intimate despite the size and grandeur. Santa Maria Maggiore is often overlooked. The piazza around it is a little urbanely busy, and the neighborhood can seems somewhat rough around the edges. But walking into the basilica is like stepping into another world altogether. Although majestic it is somehow intimate. Take the time to sit (whether there is a mass going on or not) and look up at the ceilings covered in 'gold'. And make sure to pay homage to the grave of Bernini that is also in the basilica.
Put it on your route!. Beautiful interior and has the remains of the original manger from Jerusalem (apparently). Even if churches are not your thing, this is worth a visit.

Opulent.. We chanced upon this church while walking around the vicinity of our hotel. It looked grand but unassuming from the outside but once inside...oh my, what a site. You can't help but notice the intricate details. While marvelling at the magnificent ceiling, I asked one of the guards if those were real gold. He told me that church contained around seven tons of gold donated by Queen Isabel of Spain. Wow! Definitely worth a stop when you're in the area. You can take photos but no flash. It's very close to Termini station.

Great place to visit. We had no intention of going in to visit, never heard of it, only went there because it was so near our hotel. What a jewel we would have missed! You can take photos and for sure take your camera! Vatican agents guard the place and you can see why, beauty everywhere and confession in about 20 different languages
Beautiful mosaics. Let yourself be captivated by the beautiful mosaics here! Don't miss the relics of the manger of Jesus!
A grand and quiet Basilica. We stayed fairly near the Basilica and saw it inside and out, day and night. It is a magnificent building worth spending some time at.
wow. every bit as good as the Vatican,but on a smaller scale.ceiling is so ornate and the service we saw moved my wife

Well Worth a Stop!. This lovely Basilica is one of the Papal churches, and truly worth a stop. The back side of this piazza was located on the quiet Via Torino just down the street from our hotel. We almost skipped this but we'd so glad we didn't!! As you wade your way through the ubiquitous vendors, you make your way up the stairs to this beautiful church. The art work found throughout Rome is mind boggling, and this is yet another example of such beauty. The doors...amazing! As a show of respect, you're allowed to photograph but without your flash, so be advised. Inside you'll find an alter that holds the actual remains of Jesus' manger as well as incredible mosaics and sculptures. Feast your eyes, so beautiful! There is a lovely little gift shop that is run by nuns where you can buy little souvenirs, many of which had been blessed.
Majestic Papal Basillica. Beautiful church well worth visiting. So impressed I went back for a second visit the following day.
Our Blessed Mother. Beautiful Church dedicated to our Blessed Mother.Contains relic of the Cradle of Jesus. One of four Papal Basilicas

Nice. Rome is full of beautiful churches. This is certainly one that is striking but like one reviewer said it is not St. Peter's Basilica. If you have the time to visit all the churches, put this one on the list.
Not St. Peter's but just as striking. Visit this church its one of the best, the mosaics and they natural light to highlighting key areas inside. Enjoy a immense scale church without the huge crowds

Nice church. Always visit this church when I'm in Rome. Beautiful tiles. Do look up when you are in front of the church, to the ceiling of the balcony. Amazing mosaic.There is also a little museum inside. Go right at the entrance.
very impressive. It is very beautiful and magical place. We very recommend to read about the basilica and visit it. Pay attention to the facade and mosaics. Especially beautiful when the sun

Spectacular. A spectacular Sistine Chapel. Historic religious relics. The burial place of popes and saints. But it's not St. Peter's!
This basilica is a true treasure. Easy to visit, not to be missed.
Santa Maria Maggiore. A very impressive site, well worth the visit. Amazing frescos. The church is very close to the termini area and easy to access.

A historic treasure. As beautiful as the Vatican Museum or St. Peter's Basilica in many ways. We stayed for the daily mass (and it was 85 percent empty). Going mid-morning or mid-afternoon for best photos. Tip: To the right corner of the main entrance, there is a shop selling religious articles and they had the cheapest prices in Rome.

A quiet out of the way Church. If you are in the area, put this on your list.. Magnificent! A bit out of the way but worth the trip. St. Peter's Basilica gets all the press but this is also just as beautiful.

great big church, excellent little museum!. My beloved and I came to Rome for the marathon and spent the days leading up the race walking to churches to see them and the art they contain.This church was easy to get to, had no lines or crowds, and was filled with good things to see, including some amazing later afternoon light streaming through the windows.Not to be missed was the little museum in the basement. It is filled with great decorative arts like chalices, vestments, architectural draws and the like. Well worth the 3 euro price of admission.
Yet another church to visit. Beautiful church inside. Easy walking distance to all the other Ancient Roman ruins. Easy access from the metro.

Interesting basilica..add to your list. This basilica celebrates the Holy Mary and built in 432 A.D. In the apse are mosaics from the 13th century. In the nave, there are mosaics that are considered the world's oldest and best preserved. There is a large silver urn that is purportedly containing manger fragments. To the right of the area where the manger fragments are located is Bernini's tomb. I expected it to be quite elaborate but it is a tile on the floor that is engraved. He invented the look of Baroque and laid out St. Peter's Square, designed the fountains in the Piazza Navona and the sculpture of St. Teresa in Ecstasy to name a few. This basilica is near the Termini station. Be sure and go to Santa Prassede which is very nearby. This church does not close during the afternoon.

Lovely old church. Away from the bustle of St. Peter's. A different world. Most visitors treat it with the respect it deserves. Interesting how the paintings are mostly high quality art but on the sides of the nave ceiling decidedly rustic. Gorgeous.
Worth it!. Liked it very much. Lots of embellishments. Very nice, very nice indeed.Your neck will get worn out on this one..
Beautiful Experience.. As we were on a pilgrimage tour, we went to a Mass for 4 days in this church. Just to see the glory of the inside takes your breath away.

Impressive. After attending Sunday mass here (which can be difficult for a non-Italian speaker but there are regular masses every hour of the Sunday morning) - we wandered around the Basilica. It is very beautiful and worth a look. Like all the churches we visited in Rome this was free to enter but donations welcome. Not too many tourists groups around which could spoil the enjoyment of such an impressive building.
Beautiful, peaceful church. This church is free to enter. The church has beautiful mosaics, marble, flooring and decor throughout. Only 10 minute walk from Termini station and a must see.
great place to see. It's one of those churches you should see.. It's absolutely fantastic . Don't be in hurry, feel it and then you can disso;ve in it's greta atmosphere..
Beautiful unique church. Beautiful unique churchWhen you are in Rome, be sure and visit this church.It is a church and a museum of art.

Disappointing tour of the Loggia. I agree with the other reviewers that this basilica is worth visiting. We were, however, very disappointed with the tour of the Loggia costing 5 Euros each. We wanted to take the archeological tour but we were told that we should take it after the Loggia tour. We therefore assumed the one ticket covered both. It doesn't. The guide, Francisco (?), spoke very softly and I could not understand most of what he said. When I made a special effort to stand close and listen all I heard were corny jokes about pay me more to open these doors or where is my volunteer to open a door. I learnt nothing from this guide and the only thing of real interest was seeing the staircase designed by Bernini.When we heard that this same guide was going to lead the archeological tour we decided to skip it.Very disappointing.

More than beautiful. If you like churches as I do, then this church is a must see when you are in Rome. From Rome’s Termini fronting Via Giovanni Giolitti, take either Via D. Manin or Via Gioberti and walk 5 to 10 minutes to The Papal Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore. You will be greeted by a piazza dominated by a water fountain and a column of the Virgin Mary. It rained really hard on the day I visited this church and the sun was just coming out behind the clouds that November morning. For me taking pictures of the wet piazza was a bonus using the fountain and column as props. The Santa Maria Maggiore is right in front and you will think that it is just another church façade. The exterior is unassuming but lo and behold, the interior of the church is awesome and really beautiful. The design and architecture of the interior is pleasing to the eyes. Check the details of the ceiling and even the flooring and imagine the labour of love done by the artisans to make the Santa Maria Maggiore interior really amazing. I sat on a bench at a quiet corner and just enjoyed looking at the shadows of the columns (the sunlight was coming from the other side) in contrast to the lights on the upper walls and ceiling showing their intricate design. Be sure to bring your camera and if you like details, at least 2 hours of your time will be spent taking pictures and at the same time saying wow!
Must see.. A magnificent building but do visit the archaeological site with remains going back to the first century discovered by accident when the main building started to subside.
Must see. What a wonderful church, it was very close to where we stayed. Beautiful paintings and artwork. We went during the day and there were few people which was nice.

ignore the exterior, the interior is splendid!. This church is located in its own piazza a few blocks from Termini station. The exterior gives the impression that the church might be closed, but don't let anything stop you from trying to go in the front doors. Inside it is splendidly constructed and decorated, as befitting a place that holds relics from the birth of Jesus. It also hosts the tomb of Bernini (who gave us many beautiful and inspirational works around Rome!) on the right side of the main altar area, embedded in the floor. Take your time looking through this marvelous church (and offer a prayer of thanks while you're there). There are bathrooms on site if you need to take a break while there.

Magnificent. Easy to overlook church - it's big and prominent but the outside belies how fantastic the inside is. Well worth an hour or so. The audio guide machine inside on left is worth listening to, we looked round, listened to the guide the looked round again with new eyes!
Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore. One of the four Basilicas in Italy. Free entrance and five minutes walk from the Termini. Well worth a detour.
A stunning church. Free attractionThe interior of the church is breathtaking, beautifully maintained, peaceful. Photos are allowed.Just find a place to sit and look up....

Gem of a Cathedral. This is one of the four papal basilicas in Rome, along with St. Peter, St. John Lateran, and St. Paul Outside the Walls. It is located near Termini, the main train station. Inside it is a beautiful treasure and well worth seeing. There is also a museum under the church with objects from its history and papal items.
Amazing. It's one of those places when you go in it takes your breath away. From the outside it looks like a ruin but it really is breathtaking well worth a visit.
Beautiful. This is my favourite church in Rome, absolutely stunning. Well worth putting a coin in the box for the lights too, absolutely beautiful.
Stunning. We were absolutely stunned when we went inside. We were staying close and had walked past a few times. Went in on the third day of our holiday and were blown away. Gorgeous

So Beautiful!. This was my favorite church in Rome. I attended the Latin Mass on Sunday morning and it was very beautiful. This church just seemed warmer and more inviting to me than some of the others, probably from all the gold on the ceiling, which legend says Christopher Columbus brought from the new world. Tucked under the altar are fragments from the Manger (so says St. Helena, but who am I to argue). The art is amazing.

Truly Magnificent. I always like to visit this church when we're in Rome, its size and splendour always amazes me. It has a really nice atmosphere and its size is not stark and overpowering as in some churches. It has a beautiful gold coffered ceiling and magnificent marble columns. The mosaics are its most famous feature, those in the aisle and the triumphal arch are from the 5th century, the apse are 11th century and in the loggia medieval highlights include a 13th century enthroned Christ which are beautifully illuminated at night. Bernini is also buried here. The sculpture of Mary holding a crucified Christ is really moving. This is one of the four main churches in Rome after St Peter's.
Fascinating. A must see in Rome, take the guided tour up to the mosaic and Bernini staircase. Beautiful. The guide was so accommodating, translating for us along the way!
I was happy I went in. We walked to the church at around 6pm from Termini. The piazza behind this church harbors some doubtful characters-dont walk by yourself.

Often overlooked but worth visiting. This magnificent basilica is often overlooked but it contains the other Sistine Chapel and the tomb of Pope Sixtus V. The 13th mosaic and the ceiling donated by Pope Alexander Borgia are fabulous.

Wonderful. From the outside the Basilica does not offer the feeling that you are going to enter into one of the most beautiful churches in Rome, but then when you go in the paintings and statutes are marvelous.
One of my favourite cathedrals. fantastic functioning cathedral near termini station. beautiful artistry inside and a service we witnessed was incredible. well worth a visit.
Beautiful church. (Basilica of Saint Mary Major) is owned by the Holy See so is a papal basilica. Magnificent inside! It is here that the sculptor Bernini is buried.

Rome Holiday. This Basilica is beautiful and very imposing from the outside watch out for the approaching beggars directly outside some of them even rolling around on the floor.The little tat shop next to it isn't overpriced so don't feel the need to shop around.prices are pretty much the same everywhere you go except for the Vatican for obvious reasons.Definately worth a visit!!!!!
Stunning. Beautiful Basilica so much to see need at least 30 mins, so much history and beautiful decoration. This is one of the 4 you should see.

A little Basilica San Pietro.. A wonderful church few blocks away from the Termini Stazione. It is a worth visit. If you are Catholic there is a regular service of confession by Dominican Friars in a few languages. Great for meditation and prayer.Thanks for reading.

Worth a visit. We passed this church so many times, that we had to go in. Inside it was beautiful and you could sit & contemplate, the alters & paintings were outstanding.Don't walk past make sure you send some time here!
Beautiful at night. we went there for a short trip. Well it is certainly one of the places one should not miss in Rome. Beautiful place accentuated by lighting at night.

Beautiful Basilica. A truly beautiful Basilica. You walk in and the ceiling takes your breath away. Even though we are not Catholics we still listened to Mass to take in the whole experience. We were pleased we went.

Feel the space. Coming to Basilica, first walk around it, to see its beauty from both sides, when clouds are coming - it's look as a miracle. Going inside, walk slowly, as there are plenty of niches and nuances that you don't want to miss

Humbling experience. We visited on Epithany, January 6 and the morning mass commenced as we entered. We speak no latin but we were awestruck and humbled by the chanting, the hymns and the ambiance. And female priests as well, quelle surprise !

One of the better basilicas. Great location and very easy to find. This basilica is one of the best ones in Rome. Although most basilicas get very repetitive this one stands out for being larger and having more statues and better pictures in general.

Go and see the Holy Crib. Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore is an impressive piece of art. But more impressive is to visit the reliquary of the Holy Crib of Jesus Christ which can be found inside.No fee entrance
must go. When in Rome, just go once and you will keep returning there again and again. The place has a special magic
Very impressive church.. Very impressive church. It was one of the churches that we liked the most. If you are in Rome you don't want to miss it.

A must see. we did not hear or know a lot about this church, we stayed quite close by and walked past it a few times until curiosity got the better !! and what a magnificent church if you get the chance this is a must see when you visit Rome

Worth a visit. This church is worth a visit if your in the area. Very pretty inside. Also enjoyed seeing all the confession boxes with different languages, handy if your not from Italy. Although we are not Christians and are strong followers of a different faith we still very much enjoyed our look around.

Amazing church. It was described in the guide as a one of the most beautiful churches in Rome and it really is. If you are nearby, you must go inside and marvel the surroundings, and enjoy the peace away from the busy city.
Pretty. Quite a pretty church, we popped in on our walk to San Pietro in Vincoli, well worth a detour if you have time.

Not that impressive on the outside but go in!. Not a great looking building on the outside & looks to be somewhat shut but don't be put off its well worth a look round, just to marvel at the spendor inside, its free so take a look, they don't mind you taking photos, & there are places to sit inside to take in the remarkable workmanship! I suspect it looks better in Summer & no doubt you can sit on the steps outside with a ice-cream, we went in January it was raining!

The most. The most perfect of the surviving Constantinian basilicas.However do not miss San Sabina on the Aventine. This is the problem with Rome. It really does take years to see; if not a life time.

A Jewel Box. This basilica is truly magnificent. There is so much gilding and gold leaf here, it looks like a jewel box. The mosaics are beautiful and they are from the 5th century. This is also where the Capella Sistina is, where the wood from Jesus' crib can be seen. This church was not crowded, either, so you can just go around and take in all the beauty at your leisure.
Great building. Fantastic art work in this church right in the centre of the city, well worth a visit to compare with the other buildings
great place to be there. we enjoyed being tot his this great place. there was too many crowd, however we felt really happy being there

A unique place. Ok it's not St. Peter's Basilica, but it's gracious, full of beauty, with lovely details, a must in your stay in Rome. Before entering, give a full round in the outside, then seat besides the front door, by the fountain, regarding the door. Make a pause, trying to imagine the inside, and then, present yourself, and let you in. Let your soul feel gracious towards this jewel of beauty.

Amazing CEILING and FLOOR. Immense in size with an awe-inspring gilded ceiling, we went to Mass at Santa Maria Maggiore. It's in a rough neighboorhood, but it's near Termini, and there are MANY things to do in that part of town - just north of the fun and trendy Monti district. The floor of Santa Maria are all these unique tiles where no two designs are repeated.
Beautiful!. He had the chance to attend Mass there, and it was a traditional celebration, in Latin, by a Cardinal, with an amazing choir.

Must see. There are a lot of churches in Rome obviously but this one is very unique. While I was there there were three different masses and Requiem going on, very cool. The ceiling is amazing the number of Confessionals, epic definitely a must-see among the churches.

Spectacular. Although under some scoffold and my visit was on a gray damp day I could easily pictur a lovely sunny day sitting on ur coat eating ice cream and admiring the view fron the expensive vantage points outside the church. Very special building with interesting side streets also pick up the tour bus by here
Wonderful Church. St Mary's is part of the Holy See and a definite must see. We visited the church on the last day of our stay in Rome just before we boarded our ship. Must See

Must see!. Oh my gosh! This is at the top of my list of favorite places to visit in Rome. We were fortunate to attend Mass in one of the side chapels and go to confession. We spent quite a bit of time in here. Love, love, love. The neighborhood surrounding it is a bit sketchy but expect that in Rome. There's a small gift shop and bathrooms available.

The largest church in Rome. The Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore is one of the seven pilgrimage churches in Rome, and a major basilica belonging to the Vatican, and therefore is not in Italy itself. On the piazza in front is the largest column in Rome taken from the temple to Constantine. Built originally in the 4th century, it has been enlarged and enriched many times over the centuries. There is much to see here: 5th century mosaics, its own Sistine Chapel, relics, and a triumphal baldacchino. Among the many treasures is a precious icon that reputedly saved the city from the plague. The golden ceiling is said to be a gift from Fernando and Isabel of Spain from their New World conquest's gold. Another MUST to see.

An unexpected treasure. We literally slipped in to this Basilica on our own one night on our way out for dinner and stayed for quite some time mesmerized by the magnificent artwork in this Basilica. There is a particularly fine marble statue of Mary and the child Jesus beautifully done and a sharp contrast to the pieta in St. Peters. This statue reflects peace and contentment in the relationship between Mary and Jesus while the Pieta in St. Peters reflects the depths of pathos. There is a nice gift shop outside the main entrance to the right with very helpful people!Pat

Beautiful. We arrived in Rome very early on New Year's Day, and were aware that most museums and exhibitions were scheduled to be closed. A relative had told us that there was a beautiful church just a short walk from Termini station, and when we arrived at Santa Maria Maggiore, we were pleasantly surprised by what we found.The exterior is very impressive, but inside it was another story completely. The floors, walls and ceilings were beautifully decorated, and there were stunning mosaics on display. During our visit, a ceremony of some sort started, and we were treated to a wonderfully traditional procession of priests, and some beautiful Latin plainsong. The whole of the ceremony appeared to be in Latin, but we didn't stay long.A definite must if you're near Termini!

Surprising History and Elegant Basilica. Not too far from the famous sights, this Basilica is somewhat of an understatement on the exterior, but reviewing the history, it housed the popes for a good period of time and was the main seat of the Catholic Church while the Vatican palaces were being restored and created. It is fitting that the interior is really outstanding, though perhaps not as impressive as the Vatican. Still, you can tell there was a lot of time and money spent on detail and the Basilica does not disappoint.The "wood" of the crib for Jesus is found here (though I find it hard to believe that this is the real thing). It is impressively displayed and there is a very nice painting of Mary and the Baby Jesus here. If you spend a few minutes really looking around, you will see that the detail of this Basilica is really impressive. Take a look at the detail of the flat ceiling and the alter. All of it is done with incredible attention to detail.There is also a sealed door for the holy year that occurs every 25 years. In all, it is worth a side trip if you are in the area. Photos are allowed in all but a few locations within the church. This would also be a great place to celebrate Christmas Mass.

Beautiful and breathtaking. This is another amazing Basilica in Rome you have to check out. Very easy to get to from Termini station and within walking distance from the Colosseum. There was barriers up on one side and it was only the next day that we realised it is open from the other side. Check opening times and the small tourist shops beside it are very good and prices are very reasonable. Inside is just breathtaking there is so much to see and take in. I would suggest giving yourself at least 2 hours to look and see everything. A beautiful basilica. This is another basilica that you dont hear too much about but is amazing. We found the best way to find all these amazing churches / basilicas was walking around rome. Everything is within walking distance and at the end of the day when your tired just hop on a bus or metro to take you back. Dec 2013
Surprised. We stumbled upon this church accidentally and were surprised by the paintings and architecture. Well worth the it - no queues or entry fees either.

Much more assesible than the Vatican. Gorgeous, ornate and stunning Bascilia. It was so beautiful and had a rich history. We took a tour of the relics in the basement that proved to be fascinating. Not as well known as some of the churches but definitely worth a visit.

A Must See. This is a beautiful Church. The altar at the front with the pope praying is touching. The art is amazing and the Basilica is a beautiful Church that is easily accessible. Check hours of operation so as not to be disappointed. Absolutely beautiful and free.

A visit to the Basilica of St. Mary Maggiore. This Basilica is the 4th largest church in Rome and the largest dedicated to the Virgin Mary. One interesting fact about this Basilica is that it is the only church that still retains its original shape and character. The Basilica was built in the time of Pope Sixtus lll (432-440 AD). The beautiful facade by Fuga, the Romanesque campanille or bell-tower is the tallest in Rome. The interior is a sight to behold.This is one historical structure to visit on a trip to Rome.

One of the most gorgeous churches in Rome. How did we miss this beautiful basilica the first time we were in Rome? You definitely want to see it by day if possible. At night, the lights are coin-operated (in the back), so you have to run to the front of the church to take a picture while the lights are on in that section of the church.Definitely drop the 2E into the little phone booth near the rear of the church to hear all kinds of interesting information about the basilica, especially the miracle associated with this particular church. The gift shop has some reasonably priced religious articles. Buy there instead of from the street vendors.

We actually met Pope Francisc there... :). While visiting Santa Maria Maggiore, Pope Francisc was praying there and passed just in front of us. A very friendly human being, the Pope. Anyway, the location itself is worth seeing, beeing a benchmark for all monuments in Rome. Almost all confessionals were opened and in a very wide range of languages! Easy to get there, from Termini metro station.
Huge.... A must see folkes..we loved the churches!!! Do visit..the highest part of Rome i believe...I'm always struck in awe when i visited this & the other churches!!
A must see. The paintings and ambiance if the times were awesome. We were taken back by the history of the church

Beautiful church with history.. This was a beautiful church with some great history and interesting details. Worth a visit, but keep in mind it is not always open to the public. Even so, you can see a lot of interesting things from the outside. Worth a nice visit.
Closed. Went to visit this on Friday 27th, was closed to my surprise. Best to check beforehand when this is open. From the outside it looks nice indeed.

Big beautiful Church. We were staying closeby, so visiting this beautiful church was easy, but still worth a visit. We also got to go to an English Mass and Confession during our visit. So that was pretty special. They also had a little gift stall, where I bought some very reasonably priced trinkets....
Go Below the Altar. Beautiful basilica. I especially loved the chapel below the main alter erected in honor of the Baby Jesus. A huge marble sculpture of a monk was bowing in praying to Jesus.

One of the must see sights in a Rome. One of the most beautiful in Rome. The incredible mosaics are some of the oldest representations of Mary in Rome, but a little difficult to see because of the lighting. Make sure that you go down a few steps to see the Reliquary of the Holy Crib, which is in a magnificent gold and silver case. It is like nothing else in Rome. Take time to sit in one of the chapels and just look at the all the painting and sculptural details. If you want, they have confessionals with priests that speak multiple languages. No fee to enter.
We always come here. Every time in Rome, when we walk around Trastevere, we go into Santa Maria and light a candle. This church has a very ancient feel to it and is very beautiful.

one of the most beautiful church in Rome. This is a Basilica that means an important great church. It is very ancient and it is strangely in the middle of the square. It menas that it is like an island and the facade is only one of 4 sides you can easily see. The outside but also the inside are really nioce. The oppening hours are really long. And it is free like most of roman churches, though they are often better than a museum of another foreign city,
A Gem. A beautiful church which afforded me an opportunity to have my confession heard with no waiting due to the large amount of priests at the ready.

Largest and most splendid. of Rome's cathedrals dedicated to the Virgin Mary. That's what my notes said (from one of many travel sources.) We were tired and did we really NEED to see another church? We almost skipped it, but we were only a block away and forced ourselves to just peek in. We ended up staying over an hour, sitting in the pews, and then slowly walking all around to take in all the beauty. My head was spinning from all the gilt and marble - breathtaking! The beautiful 5th century mosaics are some of the oldest representations of Mary in Rome. The 16th century coffered ceiling is magnificent. There are numerous paintings and frescoes and a great Triumphal Arch. Down a few steps is the Reliquary of the Holy Crib (aka Crypt of Nativity) in a beautiful gold and silver case. There's a marble statue of a kneeling Pope that we found moving. We found it impossible to just "peek in" at this wonderful cathedral. It should be on your must see list.
A must see on a sunny day. This place is truly a marvel, but the Basilica is not well lit, so best to see while the sun is high and able to shine through the windows. The mosaic work is breathtaking.

Another Beautiful Church. Prior to visiting rome my wife and I wanted to visit this church along with San Palo, and San Giovanni. It was amazing to be in such a Beautiful church. The history of the church was interesting and the architecture was amazing. Highly recommended if you have 1-2 hours to spare.

Favorite- absolutely breathtaking. Walked over on our last morning in Rome. All I can say is WOW! Unbelievably gorgeous, ornate...each chapel in more amazing than the last. I will get back to Rome one day, and this is a place I will see again. Free entry, but offering boxes in each chapel. Confessionals line the walls with the languages the priest inside speaks. A service was going on in a side chapel when we were there- with a group of monks or priests chanting and singing,,,this served as the background music to my tour of the rest of the Basilica- simply amazing experience.I love to visit old churches (art/architecture/history) but this might be the all time favorite,

Beautiful & awe inspiring!!. Great sight with magnificent art!!The ceiling alone would take a day to examine!! I was annoyed at the noise and lack of respect the other tourist were showing but the whole experience thrilled me.

Beautiful Santa Maria........ This Basilica is free to enter and well worth a visit to see all what Rome has to offer. It is very impressive . Our first visit was in the evening and I was disappointed that my images were poor so we made a return visit to explore and take much better images in the daylight. Small peaceful chapels cascading with art work and beautiful decorations all in adoration to our Lord and Mary.

lovely. This Basillica is worth a trip to. Although don't make the same mistake as I did. We walked up all the side streets, up all the hills to reach this basillica and when we reached it there were barriers around the outside. We thought this was the main entrance so didn't bother looking around (the doors are on the other side...) It is really big inside and it is a nice place to go to and eat somewhere where it is not as busy and the city centre.
Beautiful. We had walked past this church several times and were finally drawn in. The entrance is around the back, not up the grand staircase. The inside is just beautiful. Its well worth a look.

amazed to see the wood from the manger. another beautiful Basilica in a city full of beautiful churches.Again we were lucky to be there for Mass, in one of the side altars.We visited the little chapel downstairs where there is a huge statue of Blessed John Paul praying before the reliquary.I would certainly recommend a visit if time permits.
Lovely Bsillica. As there are so many churches to visit eventually you don' appreciate as much. This one however is lovely. Very nice art work.

One of the oldest basilicas. We were lucky to arrive to Santa Maria Maggiore exactly when the sunday mass celebration started. It was so special. Beautiful from inside. I felt so at ease.Our first day in Rome. Just had our breakfast and coffee, sunshine all around and after a few minutes of walking we popped in. The mass started. I didnt follow my watch and we arrived at ten.It felt like a sign. There are a few very special moments in our lives and this one I will remember for long.
Quiet Beauty. So much beauty in one place, and the serentiy of the church fills you. Make sure you go downstairs to see the statues and art work that is on the lower level.

Big and empty. I saw plenty of churches in Rome but this one just didn't do it for me. I found it to be more like a marble warehouse, than a church. Very large, but nowhere near as well-decorated as some other churches in Rome. I recommend you skip this one, nothing to see there.

Magnificant!!!. One of the four major churches of Rome and one of the earliest it was was of the first named in honor of Mary. Look to the ceiling - it is covered with the first gold brought from the new world. Look on the floor that you are walking on; extremely ancient and beautiful. The first chapel on the left front is extremely important and a thing of great beauty. It contains the famous picture of Mary called Salus Populi Romani and is the icon before which Pope Frances prayed the day after his election. Allow 2-3 hours to explore every nook and cranny of the church--several popes are buried here- and time for the great museum in the basement--another hour or so. Don't miss it on the very top of the one of the 7 hills of Rome.
Very cozy basilica. It is a breathtaking beauty and sacred place for Christians.Great architecture, interior and icons inside!Very famous church.

a great church. most of the european churches look alike but the ones in Italy tend to be more special in architecture and everything. this one is amazing and also the streets surrounding it are a lot of fun to walk in them and get a taste of rome.

Well worth a visit. This is a less crowded Basilica but well worth a visit. It has many nice art pieces to enjoy or to just sit down and let your mind rest for a while before heading out on the busy streets again.

Great very old church. Different from most.. This was just up the street from our hotel. It dates back to the 4th or 5th century and is decorated differently from most of the Duomo's we visited. I recommend it for a change of pace from the later churches.

Fantastic. Took part in the Polish mass while we were there. This place is magical with the remains of Pope Pius 5th actually on one of the altars. Beautiful church and full of pictures/paintings/sculptures. We didn't want to leave as it was so peaceful. Priests were mostly multi lingual which was really good for all the tourists from other countries as well as Italy.

Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore. Built in 432 AD, this is one of Rome's oldest churches. They also lay claim to being the first church dedicated to the Virgin Mary. When you go into the church, you are technically entering the Vatican and leaving Italy because the church is a Vatican possession. Inside there is a glass case with an urn that supposedly contains several pieces of wood that are said to have come from Jesus' crib. There are also some of the oldest and best preserved mosaics here along with the tombs of Pope Sixtus V and the sculptor Bernini, who it sometimes seems did all the sculpture in Rome.

My favorite church in Rome. Be sure to bring coins to use in the box that controls lights to shine on the mosaics! This gem is in the trestavere neighborhood and is a fine place to begin your exploration of the ancient neighborhood. Note they close from noon to 1pm each day
Gorgeous church. The first church I visited on my 6 night trip to Rome and it definitely set the bar very high. I love visiting churches and this is one of many beautiful ones all over Rome.

Duck in and Wander. It doesn't take long to see the highlights of this wonderful church, a church that, according to tradition, was placed here because the Virgin Mary told the pope and a wealthy Roman to construct a church in her honor on the spot where snow appeared--in August, A.D. 358. Don't miss the two sumptuous chapels across from one another or the huge baptismal font. You can rent audio guides for a complete tour.

Good. We didn't really plan to go Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore, we walked pass,saw the church and decided to go in!! it is a beautiful and large church! and there are many climbing stairs in front!!! should go if you have extra time

Beautiful. Look at the marble, be in awe of the Madonna and the beautiful art. The basilica is a masterpiece! When you are done visiting the divine, go outside and enjoy roasted chestnuts and a show. There are lots of musicians, street artists and vendors. Grab a coffee and enjoy the people watching, but watch your stuff!

Very Interesting. Our last few stops were also Basilicas; Santa Maria Maggiore and La Scala Santa. Both were exquisite and large, the later filled with many climbing the stairs on their knees. I was amazed at the amount of people climbing on their knees, it looked painful.

Very good. could not get enough of the Basilica/the Square/the ambiance.Monumental in every way. loved it. If you take the Hop On Hop off Bus it stops right across the street. can't miss italso great to take the time to have an Espresso in a nearby cafe and sit outside overlooking the Basilica. Very realxing

All Souls Day. Was here for a Mass celebrating All Souls Day 02-Nov-13 --- solemn feast commemorating those who have died and are now in Purgatory. Built A.D. 432. The church is dedicated to Holy Mary, the mother of Jesus.

Glorious. What a beautiful place! Do walk around, go up the steps and get an inside glimpse of this most lovely Basilica. Even if you do not go inside the architecture itself is well worth a visit. One of Rome's special and wonderful attractions. Remember to put it on your must do list.

Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore Beautiful Church. This is an ornate church and not well known to all visitors to Rome. So if in Rome please go visit it. It is beautiful and within walking distance from Termini Station. It is also not well marked on the free map. It is known as the Popes Church. Lot of art and sculptures to see within.

One of our favourite places in Rome. Make sure you do not miss this Church.....you will not believe what you see when you walk through the doors. Absolutely stunning and for all fans of Gallileo, this is surely a must on your Rome tour...

Early mosaics. Beautiful mosaics although hard to see because of low light levels. Silver reliquary with part of Jesus' manger (although it was more like a packing case) in a lovely little half subterranean chapel. Shame about the enormous sculpture of a kneeling pope which ruined the chapels ambiance. We visited the small attached museum but not the best I've ever been to.

There are churches, and then theres this. . I went into the bascilica expecting much of the same as every other church and bascilica, I was amazed. My quick stop turned into two hours. In comparison this is quite small but the main room is flanked on the left by about 4 seperate alter rooms. Three of which had services conducted on the Wednesday I was there. There were a lot of tour groups but most of them are small groups. There was a choir singing when I arrived and it added to the experience. Whilst I was there three other groups arrived and I was treated to singing by Spanish, Malaysian and English groups.Set aside at least half an hour, photos are allowed except in two areas which are clearly marked. The gift shop is not expensive and the people are not pushy, they are happy for you to browse. Toilets are extremely clean and free. There is a museum and a history of popes and relics for additional fee but again its clearly marked.

Wow. The exterior of the basilca makes u think of actually what ull see inside , it's a great surprise element once u walk in u r left with ur mouth open ... One of the few cathedrals with no queue n few tourists but def a must see !!!!

Impressive and unexpected.. I had been to Rome many times, but I had never been around this basillica. We went in after dinner to take a look, and we were glad we did. While it might be overshadowed a bit by other places in Rome, it compares very favorably with other churches or cathedrals in Europe.
Definitely worth a visit. Beautiful church. The highlight is the oldest icon of the Virgin Mary. Very peaceful sitting in the side chapel.
Simply Breathtaking. We must have seen two dozen basilicas, churches, and other religious buildings while in Rome this month...All were incredible and worth stopping in to see
Must see. Gorgeous church in Rome. Located near the train station, so there's no excuse not to stop in really fast. The place where the Pope celebrates his first mass. Amazing ceiling detail.
Little secret. Amazing secret void of tourists. Beautiful dome, smaller more decorative pantheon like dome. The brick ruin exterior hides doesn't give away the incredible ornate interior.
Absolutely beautiful ceilings.. You must take the time to visit the inside of this Basilica. Though many churches and cathedrals are magnificent, the inside of this one is breath-taking!
A must see!. In this church you can view the wooden crib that Jesus was laid in after birth. Truly a must see while in Rome.
Beautiful church. We toured the basilica during our time in Rome and were very impressed with the construction, size and the artwork throughout the basilica.

SIESTA TIMEOUT. Climbing the hill and a notice on the fence:"closed 14:00 open 16:00".How this can happen in a city of tourism and religion? This church is one of the most advised in our book but became a real dissapointment......

Beautiful church. This church was on my list of places to visit in Rome. Being Catholic, I had read of Pope Francis' visits to this church to pray before the famous icon of the Blessed Virgin located in the side chapel. The massive interior of this church is beautiful with the ornate ceiling being one of the highlights.
Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore. It gets four stars for a reason. It has lovely apse mosaics, but they are all but impossible to see because there is no lighting on them.

Beautiful!. From the moment you step in the door you are struck with the sheer beauty of this church. It's not over-the-top baroque, but there are plenty of baroque elements here. After all, this is Bernini's final resting place.Take your time here to admire the many mosaics and be sure to go under the altar to visit the remains of the manger.There's a lot to see here so be prepared to spend an hour or two.
Impressive. This is a very impressive basilica. It could use a cleanup on the exterior of the building. The rear is just as impressive as the entrance and not to be missed
Overwhelming basilica. Just came across this basilica as we were walking back to our hotel but make a point of visiting. Overwhelming place and absolutely massive.
Beautiful Church. This church was very close to my hotel and on my last day in Rome I just took a walk to this church. The church is rich in history and beauty.

Great Basilica. This is one of the Main Basilicas in Rome, the interior is quiet impresive, was my first time in an emty church!. the side chapels were great and the ceiling is amazing, its simple a great building, lost of marble and great details.

An oasis near Termini. Each of the basilicas is so different. This one is set on an island near Termini. Guide books suggest Victor Emmanuel metro which is a nicer walk but Termini is probably slightly nearer. Rich interior decoration with on the outside the highest steeple in Rome. Don't miss it!!

Magnificent. Take time to go and see this Basilica in Rome. Its a 5th century church which has gilded ceilings and wonderful chapels. Don't make the mistake of going around the back and thinking its closed !

Beautiful Basilica. We had a little trouble finding the entrance but so glad we remained persistent. This is a beautiful church. It has several small chapels within & while we visited there were masses going on in 3 of the chapels. Wonderful domes & artwork. No charge & make sure you are covered up or you will not be allowed in. They have a nice little gift shop as well.
Worth a visit on the eastern part of the city. This is one of the four major basilicas in Rome. Make sure you visit the crypt under the main altar. That silver urn is really something special.
Beautiful church. Very beautiful church and very actively in use. Ceiling paintings are very beautiful. The church really took my breath away.

Stunning Maria Maggiore. Very special place.The ceiling is stunning and takes your breath away.Its full of wonderful works of art and has a peaceful ora about it.Pope Frances visted the Basillica when we were in Rome its one of his favourite churches and you can see why when you have been around the venue

Impressive Ceiling. This is a huge church with very nice nave and interesting history. It is worth the 2 euro to listen to the audio commentary. Its look like a phone booth and located on both sides near the entrance.

Another beautiful church. This church is in a piazza with a tall obelisk with Mary and the Baby Jesus on the top of it. The church is stunning; well worth stopping in. Remember your knees and shoulders must be covered in all churches in Rome.
Amazing. What a beautiful building, totally amazing, Lethe ceilings were amazing. Don't forget to look at the floors also.

Breath taking. The simplicity of line and the elegance of the marble worked into the panels really made this church special for me. even had a moment of quiet in front of the remains of Jesus's crib...
Hope you can go in.. We could not go in the day we were there. There was a camera crew there, possibly doing a documentary. It is lovely from the outside. Next visit I hope we can see it
Another must see. A bit of a walk from hotel Trevi, but well worth it. Amazing art and history. Rome is such a gorgeous city!

Wanted to know more. Would have loved an audio tape for this venue feel even with the purchased guide book we missed out and will be going to the internet for more information especially as this was one of our main attractions for our visit to Rome.
great place to visit. Just walk in and view this magnificent building. Make sure you rmember to cover up shoulders and knees when visiting Basillica's

INCREDIBLE. WOW. Very beautiful. So much to see. Bring comfortable walking shoes. Glad I went. Would like to go back without tour guide. Not enough time to really experience the full effect. If you can go on your own so that you could appriciate it more. Would love a second chance to do it all over again.
Another beautiful Basilica.. We kind of stumbled upon this Basilica while walking around the neighbor hood while waiting for our hotel room to be ready. Very glad we did.

has to be seen. Regardless of your religious beliefs this is one visit you have to make whilst in the city, along with the many other inspiring churches. Just take in the shear magnificence and beauty of the decor and sense of calm. We did not experience a service and can only imagine how more wonderful it would be if we had.

Beautiful. We discovered this church while walking around. It is a lovely church which is not as well known or as ornate as St Pauls but was certainly not as busy. It was fascinating that there was the Meridian line through the church with all the information and a pendulum with information about Galileo.

Mosaics from before the fall of Rome. This whole church was gorgeous. Especially the mosaics lining the church that have been there since just before the fall of Rome. We were there for the Sunday morning pass and the service was in a mix of Latin and Italian. It was beautiful.

Beautiful church and must-see museum. An awe-inspiring church. Brilliant decoration and artwork. ?2 for a 2 earpiece guide (at a stand alone machine) is a bargain for all the history you get. Don't forget to visit the museum (exit out to the right from the shop) which has some great artefacts. My favourite church we visited. Bear in mind the dress code - no above-knee shorts or vest tops and remove caps.

Renowned, but really.... ...not among my favorites of the many churches we visited in Rome. Though large and ornate, to me it did not verge on the spectacular, as so many Roman churches do. So, worth a look, but you'll see better, I'll bet, Located in a scruffier part of Rome, but still safe. If you're going there, you should also make a visit to nearby S. Prasseda to see the Byzantine mosaics. Be aware that you are expected to dress appropriately to enter any Roman church, especially if you are female. Admission is free. Churches are often closed from noon until 3 or 4.

Top Rating. Easily reached by a short walk from Termini station it is easy to overlook this site but don't. You might miss one of the more spectacular sites in Rome. Very impressive inside and it functions as a proper place of worship. Not too crowded & maybe only unguided but surrounded by restaurants to make it a must to include in Rome.

Breathtaking. Having seen St Peter's and then coming here it was a bit of a relief ! It's still spectacular and impressive but without the crowds. Although it was still very busy, there seemed to be a bit more of a tranquil feel and you could actually stand still and take things in. We should have taken the audio tour but they had run out, stupidly I was wearing shorts and luckily they had some overalls so I could cover my legs.
My Favourite Church in Rome. The Church of Mary Major is my favourite church in Rome because of it's sense of serine prayer. In particular the side Chapel where the blessed Sacrament is exposed.

Is it even open?. This was basically a very large church that was partially fenced off, and I never saw anyone go inside. Outside was surrounded by beggars and winos. A shame, it coulld be a beautiful place.
Impressive from the outside. The Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore is quite impressive - but sadly, no entrance... Depends on the time of year probably.
