always lovely. I love this basilica and it is so close to everything! Make sure to make it a part of your itinerary in Rome.

Favorite church in Rome. St. Peter's is grand but Santa Maria Maggiore and a few others are much more spectacular to me - and less crowded. Mosaics and chapels here lovely. Took our time admiring the grandeur of it all. Also find Bernini's family tomb to right of altar - just a simple and humble marker on the floor.

Must see. Know your history and visit the major churches in Rome. This is one of them. Contains part of Baby Jesus' crib. Very impressive. We had a mishap and the staff was very nice too. Do get the audio tour.
Beautiful. This is an amazing place to visit. I found it so moving. There is no queuing, and the Basilica is just amazing.

Beautiful. Stunning papal basillica, yet another contributing factor to a severe case of Roman Neck, the ceilings are beautiful. Please be respectful and silent, this is a functioning consecrated church!

So much to see. The Basilica is very beautiful and full of history. But if you want a little bit more than just a walk around, go towards the bathrooms and the gift shop, there is a stair going down and you can buy extra tours there. There is a museum; there is a tour of the balcony upfront (we did this one and really worth it just to see the mosaics on the facade) and there is the archeological site underneat the Basilica (that we also did). That one is a most if you are a fan of history. There are artifacts so unbelievable there and in such pristine condition, it's mind blowing. Really recommend this tour!
Closed. The Basilica was closed off, beginning with the stairs so all we could do was stand at the large and empty square and wonder why are we there.
Nice Basilica. Very beautiful artwork inside the church. All the sculptures, stain glasses inside the church are amazing. Really peaceful when we are inside the church.

Beautiful church. Churches in Italy have some of the most beautiful artwork! I toured this church several years ago and you were not permitted to take photos; this time, we were. The most amazing thing, to me, in this church is the wooden manger that was used as a cradle for the Infant Jesus. It's encased in glass and gold and is behind a glass window down a short flight of stairs. Some people doubt that it's authentic, but I believe that it is. This church is definitely worth seeing.

Absolutely fabulous. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this very beautiful, yet human, church. If you are a Roman Catholic, there are many opportunities to enjoy the sacrament of reconciliation - and different languages are catered for.
very beautiful. Very beautiful basilica, as inside, as outside. Its one of the most old christian basilica. Have to be in your must see list. reccomend

Another favorite. I discovered it by "mistake" on my first stop in Rome, years ago and made sure I would go back on my recent stay. I really like the looks of it. And I would recommend sitting on the terrace of the cafe, facing it, and enjoy the view over the basilica.

Historic and beautiful basilica. We loved that this wsa the lat building Michelangelo designed. It is simple and beautiful and worth visiting. Y can read the information or take the audio tour. It is free and worth a visit.
Beautiful basilica. Lovely church close to Termini. Well worth taking a look. It has a beautiful stained glass window that lets the sun shine through early in the morning.
Famous historic site. There is a famous statue here, with all Gothic and dark feeling, very very nice! Smaller compared to the other ones and a bit hidden, so make sure to look carefully.

Fabulous!. Wow! Nearly missed going is as thought it was closed having only previously walked past the back of this basilica - make the effort to walk round to the front and go in - breathtaking sights.
Beautiful Basilica. Mosaic, fragment of the nativity and just over all beautiful church. Make sure you have your shoulders and knees covered. Free admission
A must see in Rome. Well worth a visit, Pope Francis visited here on his first day in office. Also this is Bernini's burial place which is marked by a marble plaque to the right of the main alter.
Beautiful. You see so many churches and some seem very similar but I really enjoyed this one. It was just so beautiful.
nice!. make sure to get dressed decent. In case you didnt they will give you something to cover up. The entrance is free and there is a lot to see.

A great duomo next to Termini. Just a block away from Termini station, this basilica is worth a visit. It has a majestic building at the outside and it is a gem at the inside.Really liked the crypt and the side chapels. One can give a look at the souvenir shop inside...people are very helpful there though souvenirs tend to be a bit more expensive than the rest.

Wonderful Tour. My wife and I saw this as part of the "Major Basilicas & Holy Stairs" tour. It was one of the best tours we have had. Our tour was on 9/16 at 2:00 pm. Before the tour we were hesitant on wither it was right for us. It was very hot that day and after walking around the Vatican our feet were tired. However, this tour with the guide we had is a must do for Rome. We had an amazing time and the guide was full of information for all areas including the history, legends, and rumors. He mentioned he was a history history major, however I am not good with names. I wish I was able to remember so we could thank him by name. The tour was of three churches by bus.

Impressive!. One of the four biggest churches in Rome, it's definitely worth a visit. We actually mistook the back of the church and tried to look for the entrance. The front facade is the side with the obelisk. The interior of the church is absolutely impressive-huge columns and beautiful frescoes. Do not miss Bernini's tomb-it's actually a plaque on the ground to your right-hand side when facing the manger fragments and the apse!

Beautiful. We stumbled upon this magnificent church rather than making out to visit it and it was a lovely surprise. Less crowded than other attractions, free too, and you have time to wonder and contemplate. Awesome ceilings and floors and the whispers of a Latin mass in the chapel which I believe is hourly throughout the day. There are some nice little cafes away from the main square and gelaterias and the tour buses stop here.
Fascinating Basilica. Located near the Termini train station, this Basilica is huge, with wonderful mosaics and beautiful artwork. Free admission, not crowded, definitely worth a visit.

You must visit this church. This is a magnificent church and one you must see. The history is not like The Pantheon and the importance not that of St Peter’s but it is a church used by the Pope and is a joy to visitIf you make this the last visit of the day there are numerous restaurants in the area, I would recommend Restaurant Elettra on Via Principe Amedeo.

Don´t miss this stop!. It is worth it! So beautifull inside. I believe there are audioguide that you can download in your ipad that will walk you through the basilica. At least there is one for all Rome in Spanish, that I belive it was called Rome audioguide, that will include this church! If you don´t have something to cover your shoulders or legs, you can find something at the entrance.

Unbelievable!. We were walking back to our hotel near the Pantheon and we came across this wonderful Basilica. The interior is very beautiful and the craftsmanship is wonderful. We did not even know about this terrific find. Don't miss it!

Amazing private tour of Rome!. With a recommendation from our tour guide, John Tinto, we went off on our own to spend time at the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore. The Manger of Jesus is there! We were able to take pictures and we were even able to attend a Mass. It was a beautiful experience and not crowded (August 27, 2013)
Beautiful. Didn't have the time to go in (cruise ship) but took photos on the outside. I will definitely take the time to go in next time I am in Rome. People say it is amazing and I bet it is.

Awesome. The title of Awesome does not give the church justice. We had just peeked in after our bus tour. It is a sight to see. I would bet to a pilgrim in the 9th century this was awe inspiring. I was moved by its beauty and this is 2013 and I'm a Baptist. Worth a visit.

They have scarves you can borrow.. Like all other churches in Rome, you are required to cover yourself so you do not disturb the peace with your sexy presence. Unlike all other churches, this one actually has some scarves they will lend you so you don't have to leave without visiting. Apart from that, this is a nice church just like the 300 others in Rome :d
Worth a visit. It was very close to our hotel (Termini area). Beautiful church! One of oldest in Rome! Whey have a relic of Jesus crib.I recomend to see it!

Not just another church. We visited this site during our five day tour of the cities sites. It was a very short walk from our hotel and is one not to miss. Whilst I'm not a religious person I couldn't get over the size and splendour of the building and quality of the inside. A mix of both historic stain glass and some more modern. Try and visit during one of the many masses for an added experience. No hats or bear shoulders, though the church accommodates the later with a loan fabric shawl. Worth a visit.
Beautiful Spot. This is a beautiful Basillica and especially welcome on the hot August day I dropped in. Take your time exploring the knave and do stop in the small gift shop by the front entrance.
Beautiful. We went to mass here the day we left Rome. The picture of Mary and the baby Jesus was carried to the vigil for peace 9/7/13 from this Basilica. It dates back 2000 years.

Another amazing basilica. One of the major basilicas in Rome and containing lots of impressive art and definitely worth a visit. Beware though of the opening hours as a lot of the churches in Rome close for 3 hours from around midday.
Gorgeous. A wonderfully decorated church. Our first cathedral visited in Rome. Small crowds, comparatively. Definitely worth the visit.
perfect. this church was my first visit in Rome.. so the impression was more than excellent..lot of designs inside.. try to buy souvenirs good prices at gift shop
beautiful. Majestic beautiful catherdral. Such a wonderful and easy place to get to. Peaceful and wonderful. Well worth a visit when in rome

Huge work of art. Cant miss it, sightseeing bus tour stops right outside, hard to get a photo as so big. There are so many magnificent churches here to see, all having amazing interiors, so decorative.

another gem. apart from visiting st peters, this basilica is worth a visit. if you are going to mass try and make the 10.00 which is a latin mass & is concelebrated by about ten priests. very moving experience indeed.
Cool, literally. Like most churches, free to enter. Beautiful inside and not too crowded,a lovely break from the heat of August.
Beautiful!. This is such a beautiful church. I was lucky enough to attend mass here and it is very moving. Worth going to just to see how lovely it is but if you can attend a service you should
Overpowering. Well worth a visit. Near to Hotel Ariston. The size and atmosphere is overpowering but very busy. central with restaurants and bars.
never seen or heard. Go to it on sunday morning. You will not only see the magnificient structure and decoretion , but also hear the magnificient chorus.
Beautiful. Very Beautiful church, one of the four Patriarchal Basilicas of Rome. Free entrance / stop termini take via Cavour until Largo Esquilino.

Very serene. A definite must-see specially if you're a Marian devotee. It is just stunning. Bear in mind you have to have your shoulders and knees covered when entering the basilica. You can have mass offering if desired. A calm place to be in away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Beautiful. Don't forget to cover your shoulders up ladies and short shorts can't be worn, I was ok with shorts just above the knee. If you do forget to take your shawl they have disposable ones available for a donation

A view to die for outside our hotel window. We were lucky enough to have a hotel opposite this building and we were able to open our window and see this beautiful building every morning.We took a look inside ( knees and shoulders must be covered, they are very strict on this) and it is a stunning basilica, probably one of the best we have seen The lighting, the colours, the architecture were just amazing. Well worth a visit.

Magnificant place. I think that this Basilica can be a best starting point to get acquaintance with Rome or to say goodbye (arrivederci!) - it is very close to the main train station (Termini) and you will never go by!
Beautiful large church. Like so many of the churches of Italy, the interior is beautiful. Wonderful ceiling, walls and statues. It's definitely worth a visit.

Breathtaking. When in Rome, a visit here is always planned. It is quite simply stunning and steeped in so much beauty that you just cannot take it all in. The stained glass windows are works of art in themselves and the many altars will fascinate for hours.We normally manage to have a priest hear our Confession, which is wonderful, a real bonus. You can find the Confessional boxes with the many languages displayed to assist tourists. There is a very peaceful atmosphere within this basilica, you will feel it too.Outside at the left hand side of the min entrance, you will find a little shop selling souvenirs. It is worth visiting as the prices are very reasonable, although the owner seemed annoyed when I asked him if I could possibly have a few extra bags for gifts! He eventually gave me 3!!!!!! Nevertheless, it is a lovely little shop. I think it is named the Casa Rosario.I am already looking forward to visiting the basilica in October with my family.

Beautiful. We walked here and ended up at the back of this church and believe me it is as impressive at the back as at the front. Alas it was shut, all churches including the vatican are free to go in and look around and take pictures but remember these are churches and most of them are in mid mass when you go in.

Most beautiful church in Rome?. This is a large and very beautiful church. It is highly decorated with paintings and statues. The opening hours were different than stated in our Rough Guide. It closed at 18:00.

Lovely. I visited this church at the very end of my day-long Dark Rome Tours excursion of the Vatican and Vatican owned sites. It was an excellent way to end the day. The rather large basilica houses what is reported to be a piece of Jesus' cradle. It also is the resting place of the great Bernini. The mosaics throughout the church were stellar. I also enjoyed the baldaccino, though it was not quite as large as the one in St. Peter's Basilica. We visited in January which was the off season, so there was no crowd at all. Overall, I was impressed and thought the basilica was well worth the stop.

"Maggiore" = Major. The church is well worth seeing, but it's pretty crowded. We got incredibly lucky and happened to be there just as the Pope was paying a visit; it's one of his special favorites. Be sure to see the side chapels.

Make sure you see the mosaics on the facade. One of the artistic glories of Santa Maria Maggiore are its wonderful mosaics, some dating back to the 5th century. The mosaics decorate the nave, the triumphal arch and and the apse, but they can also be found on the facade. These were obscured, but, thankfully, not destroyed when the portico was added to the church in the 18th century.The mosaics can seen, albeit with difficulty, from outside the church. However, they can be viewed close up by joining one of the church's own tours. I have never seen medieval mosaics from such a close distance and the experience was thrilling. Not to be missed.

Spectacular and well-loved church. The interior of this church is a combination of marble and mosaic. It also contains the other Sistine Chapel. However what I most liked about it was that it was alive with its local population. The side chapels had Masses being said and sung and the confessionals we in use. So nice to be more than just a monument.

Simply wonderful. What an amazing basilica. We were lucky enough to visit this church on our last day of visit. The cieling's artwork , and spacious entrance and the beautiful vitraille work is fantastic. There was even a Mass going on inside when we entered for a visit. It is certainly worth visiting when in Rome.

It snowed on Aug 5th.... Luckily we were here on the annual festival celebrating the snow where a cardinal leads a prayer service and they drop 10's of 000's of white rose petals from the ceiling to represent the snow. It was very cool. If not for the festival experience... it was still a brilliant, ornate church that is wonderful on it's own, but probably not so much to go out of my way to see with so many other beautiful sites in Rome for a short visit.As legend goes, 1700+ years ago the architect had a dream that it would snow the next day (Aug 5) in Rome - the hottest time of year & 98 deg. F when we were here - wherever it snowed was to be the place of the Basillica they were planning. He shared his dream with the Pope and later that day when it actually snowed, they raced over to the hill and the Pope drew the outline of the foundation in the snow.

Worth Seeing. This is the largest basilica dedicated to the Virgin Mary. It is a massive church filled with beautiful marble mosaics on the floor and outstanding art. We had a wonderful private guide who walked us through this basilica rich in history.
Nice church. A must visit when in Rome. This church is magnificent every space is filled with bits of decoration, just a lot to take in. There are so many ornaments on the ceiling. Just stunning!

Beautiful and active church. Attend services while visiting if possible and be sure to allow enough time to see everything as there are many recesses to be seen. It's less touristy and more a functioning church community.

This is one of the few thing you cannot miss on Roma. Of course Roma is plenty of things that anyone must see, but I often receive the same question from colleagues coming from abroad: "I've one day, what should I see in Roma?"And my answer always include Santa Maria Maggiore. It is close to the Fori Imperiali area, so close to the Colosseum and is the most beautiful church in Rome, full of treasures collected in the fifteen centuries of its stories.

Great. It was an amazing place to visit, after it being rated so highly on trip advisor we visited and so glad we did. Not very busy and easy to find, fair few lunch places near by if you want to grab a light lunch. We were not aware but you need to have your knees and shoulders covered visiting this place but their is this stuff providing on the doors which the security people ask you to use if you dnt have a wrap.
Beautiful!. Huge Church with beautiful features! I loved the scenery outside and how it carried inside. We went right after a Mass and I was in AWWWW!
Extraordinary!. Have to go to this Basilica when you go to Rome! This is where we found out we were having a "granddaughter"!

One of the Papal Basilicas. This, along with San Giovanni in Laterano, Saint Peter's, and Saint Paul's Outside the Walls, is one of the four papal basilicas, the top four churches in Catholicism (all in Rome). It's gorgeously ornate, but difficult to navigate in some respects, and we weren't allowed in the chapel with the famous Madonna icon. We searched in vain for Bernini's tomb, and had to queue for his stairs. All in all, while magnificent in its own right, it was the least impressive of the four papal basilicas, and by far the least user friendly.

Beautiful must see church in a city of many churches. If you are going to only see a few churches, this one should be on your list. Beautiful artwork, of course, also the tallest bell tower in Rome. Nice little gift shop as well.

It's a must because of Bernini's tomb. Okay, I must be honest and admit I had walked past this church at least a dozen times and did not go in. Then, while reviewing some of the other places I had visited, and reading another TripAdvisor's review (thanks JasperrNL), I got what I was missing. The basilica isn't above any other, it is average, but this is where Bernini rest. You really need to go here if you admire his work.

Stunning. Beautiful mosaics & interior.Under the high altar is the Crypt of the Nativity said to contain wood from the Crib of JesusLocated on Via Cavour, a few mins walk from Termni station & the Colosseum.Highly recommended.

Wonderful. Not perhaps recognised as a main attraction, but well worth a visit. We even visited on Sunday morning to sample an Italian gathering of Mass. The basilica is fantastic and well worth a visit
Beautiful!!. Beautiful church inside and out. It was very nice to visit this place,is one of the best looking churches in Rome. Allots of gold inside.
Majestic church. It's the oldest church in Rome, and the four columns around the altar is similar to St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City.

Spectacular. That really is the only word to describe this church. Our hotel was very close to the basilica and so we saw this church every day. We even had breakfast overlooking it from the rooftop of the hotel.The church itself is very large and beautifully decorated inside. It holds one of the Holy Doors (only opened once every 25 years), the ceiling is made from the first gold brought back from South America and the church even has, what is claimed to be, a part of Jesus Christ's shroud.I am not religious in the slightest but this church was amazing. One of the biggest in Rome, and the largest devoted to the Virgin Mary.Beautiful on the inside and the outside, and if you can visit the rooftop restaurant and watch the sun going down behind the basilica, it truly is a magical experience.

The pope was speaking. We walked around my wife and I and suddenly we saw some men in suit and we understood that the pope was speaking inside basilica di santa maria maggiore. We got close and got some good pictures. The church was very beautiful and it was just a good experience and funny as we had not expected this. Very historical church and very beautiful.

Must see not far from termini. It's a must see especially if you are staying near stazione termini. Beautiful and rich interior and it's on your way to other places of interest. second only to St. Peter's basilica.

Awe inspiring. This Basilica was not a difficult walk from our hotel we were so pleased that we found it, as we had missed it completely on our first trip to Rome The treasures inside are just jaw dropping, I cannot think of enough superfluous to describe the Basilica.
A lot to see. A large church with a lot to see. Some research prior to a visit would be helpful so that you can look for the major features. It is a bit of a church and museum combined.

Our nearby church. This church was close to our hotel and we walked past it several times and then decided to visit the inside. This was an example of a typical church from Italy. the inside was impressive.

Wow. This basilica is beautiful and is worth the time to visit, when your there just sit and take in the surroundings its then that you really understand this basilica. It might not have the same magnificence as St Peters but its if you look carefully it has every bit the same.
Nice church. It's really nice but I like Trastevere a lot. Definitely worth a check in if you are in the local area...if you're not then just catch it next time.

Beautiful, but hot. We went to Sunday Mass at St. Mary Major. Beautiful church, but no air conditioning and it was very hot. It was crowded and it was fun to attend Mass in Italian. Gift shop is small, but nice and we bought a few items there. Beautiful art work in the church.

Put this on your list!. Beautiful. The wood from Jesus' manger is on of the relics there. The piazza is so large and traffic all around. The only negative were the panhandlers, hat, scarf, and umbrella sales persons.

Go and see it.. This was our first place to visit in Rome. It is a brilliant basilica and stunning to boot.the roof of gold and the paintings make it a very special. Its not so impressive outside, but don't let that put you off. Go.

Just Beautiful. We attended mass at this beautiful Basilica on Sunday it was a wonderful. The church was really beautiful it is considered part of the Vatican. It is also the final resting place for part of the remains of St. Catherine of Siena. Beautiful art work and a nice little gift shop.
Santa Maria. We loved this place as well. Soooo many places to see in Rome. This was one of the top places in my opinion.

Beautiful and not so crowded church. Near Termini station Santa Maria is very beautiful old church that is well maintained. If you want to see beautiful and peaceful churches, this is a good place that is not full of tourists all he time.
No lights!. This is a beautiful church with a great collection of art. Unfortunatly you have to pay to turn on the lights to see it.

The Pope came here!. Ok, so the title says it! We stayed at a bad hotel down the street (Hotel D'Este) but had a balcony and one night, after tours, the Pope held service here. It was AWESOME! The inside is beautiful...just don't take photos. They are not allowed.
Very pretty church. A beautiful church, adorned with the most amazing statues and paintings. It is very easy to find and definitely worth a visit.

Check out the carved tapestry. There is a carved stone tapestry at the front of the church hanging from the first pillar which is classic Bernini. Notice how the words flow with the wave of the tapestry.

A hidden gem. This is a hidden (or not so hidden) gem in Rome. Not too many tourists around but one of the most impressive churches you can visit. The cupulas are really fancy. My hotel was nearby. If not I would probably have missed this one.

gold and glorious music. We joined italians Christians at 10am worship in Latin in this golden basilica.
It was inspiring the hear the choir and organ blending their harmonies to worship God and the sounds reverberating around this ornately decorated church. We were only able to understand occasional words but there were plenty of paintings of bible stories to wonder at in between.

Definitely worth a visit. The Basilica was very close to our hotel and we could actually hear its clocking every day. When we finally made our way into it, Gee, I was totally amazed. It was stunningly beautiful, spacious, elegant, serene and sacred. Speaking of luxurious decor, I guess it fell short of San Pietro Dome in Vatican, but emotionally I felt more touched and somehow I simply wanted to stay there, to sit on a bench and just gaze around or empty my mind.Another thing is their confession rooms are actually operative and they can use different lanagues too. Not bad. No biggie, same as other churches in Rome. Although beautiful inside, it's small and it is not worth the trip if you are not already nearby.
My daughters favorite. One of the smaller Basilicas however we felt it had a lot of history and a very strong pull to it. This was not crowded at all even though we were there on high season.
A beautiful and spiritual place. Don't miss a trip to this magnificent basilica - the architecture, mosaics, frescoes and history are not to be missed.

Lovely but overwhelmed with tourists. SMM is one of the major basilica churches of Rome and is on the pilgrim route. It is also close to Termini and both cause it to be overwhelmed by tourists. Second to people snapping pics in the Sistine, the number of flashes going off in SMM is a bit like a Hollywood catwalk. If you can push beyond that and find some of the quieter spaces (or better yet make an early-morning visit) you will get a better sense of the reverence that the church is meant to invoke. A significant number of popes made SMM the location of their tombs. There are multiple reasons (devotion and beauty among them) and it is worth it to look past the crowds to reach back in order to find these reasons. Really worth a visit if you are a pilgrim or not, but please try to go very early before the press of people.
Impressive - but. If you have seen the Saint Pauls Bascillica in Vatican then you wont like it. But as I said It is good.

Where did the Pope put the gold from Columbus?. 10% of the gold brought back by Columbus from the New World was tithed to the church. Some of the gold was used to decorate the Pope's personal rooms at the Vatican, but the rest was used on the ceiling of this church. It is positively breathtaking. But what is even more beautiful is the Mini Sistine Chapel that exists in the church. Furthermore, it's spiritual relic is the manger that the baby Jesus laid in in Bethlehem. It is powerful to descend into the chamber and pray in front of it. Finally, it holds what is widely regarded as the truest interpretation of the Virgin Mary, and is where Pope Francis went to pray the day after he was sworn in as Pope. We were lucky to have seen this marvel of man's creativity and God's beauty. I have to highly recommend you stop in and rest here for awhile. There is so much to see and appreciate and take in.

Beautiful inside and underneath!. The inside of the church is stunning, I particularly loved the steps down to under the altar where a worship area for an artifact sad to be part of Jesus' manger is.We loved the tour of the excavation under the church - hugely interesting!
amazing. We happened upon this beautiful Basilica and it was one of the highlights of our trip. Gorgeous architecture, gorgeous church.
Gorgeous. One of the most beautiful churches in Rome. Just amazing work on the ceiling. Never crowded and close to Termini so there's no excuse not to visit!! Amazing.

One of the four key Basilicae of Rome. A lovely frontage yet it is the interior that is worth the visit. A beautiful basilica with a high vaulted ceiling and a stunning, 1920-30s stained glass window one end.

Roam freely in this masterpiece, find Bernini's grave. I've been to Rome several times and have visited the Santa Maria Maggiore every time. Not because of any personal religious connection, but because of some stunning art work on the windows, walls, and ceiling, the vast emptiness in the middle section (the church having no benches makes it very easy to walk around without being disturbed, and give you ample time to check out the ceiling), and to salute one of the greatest sculptors in history: Bernini. I was actually amazed with how little attention is paid to the grave of the great Bernini, with not a single soul (or tour group) knowing, noticing, or taking the time to look for the simple, marble gravestone on the right side of the large center-tomb that houses one of the most influential and visually present artists in Rome. The church itself doesn't help the cause either: a mere two slanted, wooden church benches protect the marble step from unknowing people wandering onto it. While you're for the other grandeur of the church, take a second to salute the master.

Very Pretty. We stayed near this Basilica, so we stopped in on our last day. It is a very beautiful church with gilded ceilings and neat mosaic floors. Like most smaller churches in Rome, they aren't crowded and it's a nice place to escape from the heat and sun.

A spiritual visit. I got more out of this basilica than the Sistine Chapel. It was quieter and less crowded plus gave more of an idea of what drove the church to build such wonders of beauty. Pay Homage to the Baroque Artist Bernini. The Baroque-era sculptor, painter and architect Gian Lorenzo Bernini (see his Ecstasy of Santa Teresa in the Cornaro Chapel of Santa Maria della Vittoria, and Fountain of the Four Rivers in the Piazza Navona) is buried in Santa Maria Maggiore. It's difficult to visit Rome and not hear his name mentioned. For someone so well known, his tomb is surprisingly modest. Set into the stair, it is to the right of the stairs going up to the altar. Whenever I'm in Rome I stop at the florist on one of the streets nearby and get flowers to lay on his tomb, a small thing to do to thank a man who so enriched the city of Rome.

A Very Beautiful Church. Pope Sixtus III was Pope from 432 to 440 and he attended the Ecumenical Council of Ephesus in 431. The Council declared Mary the Mother of God and when Sixtus III became Pope he decided to build the Church of St. Mary Major to honor her. The present church evolved through the ages and was made larger and more beautiful. The front façade was the work of Fernando Fuga and was created in 1741. It has a portico of five arcades on the lower story and three arches in the upper loggia. On top of the façade there are statues showing Popes, St. Charles Borromeo and the Blessed Nicholas Albergati. Over all are the figures of the Madonna and Child. The bell tower was Romanesque and built in the 14th century, and now is the tallest bell tower in Rome, with a pyramidal spire and with a height of 75 meters. The belfry contains five bells. In front of the church is a tall marble Corinthian column which Pope Paul V had transferred from the Basilica of Constantine located near the Colosseum. An elegant fountain was placed at its base. The façade of the apse at the back of the church was the work of Carlos Rainaldi.The interior has three naves and the central nave has a coffered ceiling in gilt wood designed by Giuliano Sangallo in 1450. It is flanked by large monolithic columns with Ionic capitals. Over these one finds 36 mosaics from the 5th century that show Biblical scenes. The floor has a Cosmatesque pavement donated by the Roman nobleman Scoto Paparone and his son in 1288. The floor was designed by the marble masters of the Cosmati family in the thirteenth century. At the end of the nave there is a triumphal arch and the central portion has a mosaic showing the Savior on His Throne. Below the triumphal arch there is a baldaquin which was the work of Fernando Fuga. It is located over the main altar.The upper part of the apse has a mosaic created by Jaime Torreti in 1295. It represents the Triumph of Mary. Jesus crowns Mary, both sitting on the throne. Beside them are many angels and saints watching the scene. The Sistine Chapel was the work of Domingo Fontana in the second half of the 16th century. It is named for Pope Sixtus V. It is in the shape of a Greek cross that is topped with a cupola decorated with frescoes. The central altar has a gilded bronze tabernacle held up by four angels and this was the work of Giovanni Battista Ricci. There are also the tombs of Sixtus V and his predecessor Pius V. The Confession is the reliquary crypt which lies before the main altar, and this was constructed by Virginio Vespignani by order of Pope Pius IX to contain the sacred relic of the Holy Crib. The crystal reliquary, shaped like a crib, contains pieces of ancient wood which tradition holds to be part of the manger where the Baby Jesus was laid. Portugal donated the reliquary which was designed by Giuseppe Valadier. The statue of Pius IX, the Pope of the Immaculate Conception, was sculpted by Ignazio Jacometti and placed in the crypt by Leo XIII.

Mosaics and columns. Founded in the 4th century, the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore (Basilica of Saint Mary Major) is one of the five great ancient basilicas of Rome. Its 18th-century exterior conceals one of the best-preserved Byzantine interiors in the city.Standing on the site of a site of a temple to the goddess Cybele, with the first church being built in the early 400s. Santa Maria Maggiore still retains its ancient layout, but most of the exterior dates from the 18th century with the only visible exterior part of the Early Christian basilica a short length of the clerestory wall, seen from Via dell'Esquilino. Origjnally, the church had an amazing position on the summit of the Esquiline Hill, but this has changed due to the growth of the city. The 5th-century mosaics on either side of the nave depict scenes from the Old Testament and alone are worth the visit. This was the first large-scale cycle of Biblical scenes in Rome. The left-hand side has scenes of Abraham, Jacob and Isaac; the right-hand side has scenes of Moses and Joshua. The amazing golden mosaics of the triumphal arch are also from the 5th century and depict scenes from the early life of Christ. The Athenian marble columns supporting the nave are the oldest parts of the church - they either come from the first basilica or from an antique Roman building. However, the shafts were reworked and the old capitals and bases were replaced during a restoration of the 18th century.A museum below the church contains Roman remains that were found here in the 18th century, including a section of Roman road, a mosaic pavement, two wells, a series of arches and narrow passages cut into the bedrock.
